It worked fine up until about a week or so ago. I‚Äôve sent feedback and have seen other comments about it doing this same thing by other reviewers. Please fix it.

title: Needs improvement
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 9, 2019
content: This is a good app (skill?) for the Amazon Echo. I use the King James version, and this app reproduces that version accurately. However, it needs some improvement. It can read a single bible verse or multiple verses within a chapter, as well as quote inspirational verses, but it cannot quote multiple chapters in a book. I'm doing a daily bible study with reading the entire bible within a year, and tried as I might, it couldn't read more than one chapter at a time within a particular book,. Also, it seems that Alexa breaks up long sentences in phrases with a slight pause. For example, Alexa reads Genesis Chapter 1 Verse 11 reads as follows:"And God said," (pause) "Let the earth bring forth grass, (pause) "the herb yielding seed," (pause) "and the fruit tree yielding fruit, (pause) "after his kind, (pause) "whose seed is in itself," (puase) "upon the earth," (pause) and it was so."I suppose this is due to a limitation in its speech software. Still, it's not very useful for bible study in my humble opinion.

title: version options, different voice please
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 19, 2020
content: First, reviewing isn't complaining. I love this skill. if you know exactly word for word what you want read you can ask for it. That's as far as this goes. I would prefer a different Bible version. I don't care for this one. I don't care for hearing Alexa reading it. However, I am still grateful for it, thank you. I make suggestions hoping for improvements I'd like to see. If they don't happen I'll still use the skill unless someone else makes what I prefer better. :)

title: Alexa Skill does not perform correctly
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 24, 2018
content: I added this to my Echo Show.  The Reading Plan does not progress and reads the same first reading every day. Alexa further irritates me by telling me I have not started the plan yet! title: Read For Connectivity Help Or You‚Äôre Gonna Hate Yourself and the Tree
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 7, 2020
content: First of all, Alexa doesn‚Äôt discover this as an actual device so don‚Äôt even bother to try that step.1. Download the Polygroup app. Do nothing with it yet.2. Go to Alexa and download the Polygroup Skill‚Äù. Link it to your Amazon account. Do nothing after.3. Plug in tree, make sure it‚Äôs off(lights not on).4. Open your WiFi settings. Look for the tree. It‚Äôll be ST-******. Connect to it. The password is located on the trees power cable. Be careful if you remove it and write it down because now ours is lost.5. Open the Polygroup App. It should ask you to connect to your home WiFi. Here‚Äôs where I figured out that it does NOT connect or find your wifi if you‚Äôre using 5G. Connect to your 2g network. It will also not tell you if you‚Äôre having connectivity issues. For some reason, every now and then my 2G connectivity gets wonky and won‚Äôt allow any devices to connect. Make sure this isn‚Äôt the case because again, it will not tell you that it cannot connect or if you‚Äôve messed up on the wifi password. It will just say ‚Äúconnection successful‚Äù.6. Make sure go back into your wifi settings and reconnect to your wifi(again, make sure it‚Äôs 2g) because it will not automatically disconnect from the tree‚Äôs WiFi module and it will kick back a message saying ‚Äúregistration failed‚Äù if you don‚Äôt.7. Hit the registration button and enter email.8. Go into Alexa app and go into ‚ÄúSkills‚Äù settings. 9. Find the Polygroup skill, select it and hit launch. Alexa will ask which Echo you want to use to command the tree and will then give you a run down on your tree‚Äôs lighting options.9. Learn the lesson that you should read reviews BEFORE you bought this piece of crap.Here‚Äôs where you need to pay attention:Alexa can‚Äôt officially recognize the device so don‚Äôt even bother having her search for it. You‚Äôll have to tell her to ‚Äúlaunch the smart tree‚Äù and THEN say the commands for the tree once she prompts you to EVERY time to get it to work consistently.It‚Äôs really not a ‚Äúsmart‚Äù tree because you can‚Äôt put it on a timer or configure it to work automatically like all other Alexa ready devices. It‚Äôs really just an extension of the trees physical light switch where it‚Äôs just easier to press it than deal with trying to get it to work with Alexa.I plan on just connecting the tree to a smart plug so it can be on a timer and just keeping it on one light setting anyway. The Alexa/Google capabilities are a joke.I hope this helps someone and saves you time. It took me two days just to get it to work and I‚Äôm pretty tech savvy. You might want to look at different ‚Äúsmart‚Äù trees than this one.

title: It will work, you just have to troubleshoot it.
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 30, 2020
content: At first go Alexa would recognize the ‚Äúsmart tree‚Äù and ‚Äúperform‚Äù the command but it wouldnt actually do anything.  I ended up nuking everything and trying again.Unplug the tree, delete personal data from Polygroup app, remove skill from alexa, etc. then set it up all over again (plug in, set up wifi, register, add skill, etc.) but this time after everything was set up, I manually set the lights to ‚ÄúWhite‚Äù and then asked Alexa ‚Äútell smart tree white‚Äù (lights stayed white, expected).  I then asked Alexa ‚Äútell smart tree off‚Äù and it turned off, then ‚Äútell smart tree on‚Äù and it went on. It‚Äôs been working flawlessly ever since.  Also worth noting you need to use ‚Äútell‚Äù not ‚Äúturn‚Äù verbiage as it obviously wont recognize it as a device.Rating 4 stars because I know how much of a pain in the a** software is to perfect and now that its working, its great.

title: Nice
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 1, 2021
content: There are two great benefits of this. 1. No more tripping over presents to turn the tree lights on and off. 2. When we wake up and go to bed the tree is no longer part of my busy routine. The lights are already on when I get up and it is a welcome part of my day.Many of the reviews indicate they could not get the app to work. Although I did download the app, I do not control the tree through the app. I have set up a routine through my Alexa app to turn the tree on and a second routine to turn the tree off. I have this command set from a completely different room and device in our home and it works perfectly. I hope the screen shot is helpful for anyone looking to simplify the season.A list of commands can be found in your tree owners manual.

title: How bad do you want to hate the holidays?
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 28, 2020
content: The year is 2020 and your able to adjust nearly everything in your house with an app on your phone or a simple command to your smart speaker. Until you buy a Christmas tree that feels like dial up internet from the 90's. You spend just over an hour walking through painfully incoherent setup steps that feel like uncle frank discussing politics after a few too many cocktails. Hang in the you'll get it figured out and you're tree will be the focal point of memories for generations to come. Finally, you get it figured out and you're a little disappointed with its lack luster abilities. The fade and blink settings are practically the same thing. So you have "9 settings". White, multicolor and 7 settings of stupid. After getting it figured out just before Valentines day your 3 old son will come along and unplug the cord from the outlet, so you can start this horrendous journey all over again. Don't buy this tree you'll regret it.

Connect your tree wifi name st-*****  with the password near the plug then follow the app to the wifi network in your house.and enable the alexa skill in your akexa app. Took the wife a min to get used to the exact wording for alexa but works well for turning the tree on or off. she wanted to add words which confuses alexa My tree has 9 functions some may have more or less. to turn the tree on or off, its alexa, tell smart tree, command. there are hiccups but if i wait a second it works.

title: My new HR pal
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 3, 2019
content: I just added this Alexa Skills app a couple of days ago and it's great! There were a few questions I asked that it didn't know the answer to, but I love that the response is: "I've sent your question to one of my human co-workers who can teach me the answer. Please ask me again tomorrow." The developers are building the content based on user experience, so it's sort of like crowd-sourcing HR knowledge. I love that I can ask questions while I'm typing on my document without having to go to another site and get distracted by all sorts of answers. It's like having an HR guru sitting right next to me to whom I can ask a question!

title: Not an app for Vietnamese fans
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 10, 2016
content: I apriciate the idea of creating this skill and have tried it. However, from the perspective of a Vietnamese, some of the facts are wrong. For example, "The Vietnamese culture is the combination of the Chinese, Japanese, Korean, and French colony influences." This is a false statement and a misleading for anyone who have never been to Vietnam before or doesn't know much about the Vietnamese history. I apologized for the strong use of words, but if the fact is true then the Vietnamese must be influenced by the American too because we're learning how to speak English in comparison to Vietnamese.

In this smartphone, data saturated era in which we live, the local chamber must strive through leveraged tech and strong strategy to remain relevant. Kudos to the Mansfield Area Chamber for taking this giant leap forward toward greater access and enhanced relevance.

title: Wow. An Industry First!
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 26, 2019
content: Congratulations to the Mansfield Area Chamber of Commerce, TX for not only being the first Chamber to launch a full functioning Voice skill with a suite of expansive 'Questions and Answers' that truly engage and improve the customer voice experience, but also integrated their membership directory into the Voice skill, which is utterly forward thinking! Hats off!

title: Great skill, just as good as its original Android app
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2018
content: This is a great skill for calculating common nitrox calculations like Maximum Operating Depth (MOD), Equivalent Air Depth (EAD), Partial Pressure of Oxygen (PPO2), and the Best Blend. This skill was written by the same developers who wrote the Scuba Buddy app on the Android Play Store (get the Pro version, it's worth it). They also created a trimmed down version of the Scuba Buddy app for the Fitbit Ionic. I can't wait for the next release which is supposed to contain calculations used by technical divers.

title: Very nice!!
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 25, 2017
content: I heard about this pending Victoria Woodhull Alexa Skill in a press release and couldn‚Äôt wait to enable it.  Very nice.  I enjoy interactive audio clips and wiki style questions/answers.  If you‚Äôve never watched the documentary on Victoria Woodhull, this makes for great, entertaining info.  I hope high school teachers introduce the Victoria Woodhull story to their students.  She was quite the trail blazer.

title: America's Victoria is an interesting skill
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 11, 2021
content: America's Victoria is an interesting skill and will teach you everything you need to know about Victoria Woodhull. Overall, the skill is fine and operates as expected. I like how you can select a quote from an APL list and how you can hear parts from a PBS documentary.

title: Grateful To Victoria Woodhull
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 9, 2019
content: What a visionary! If every woman in America knew about Victoria Woodhull, they would be eternally grateful to her and her colleagues for paving the way. We women enjoy many rights politically, socially, and in business, we now take for granted because of Victoria. What an inspiration. Thanks for educating me and my sisters. Well done!

title: Entertaining, Amazing and Educational.
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 8, 2019
content: As it is International Women's Day, I was inspired to enable America's Victoria, and was thrilled to discover a treasure chest of wonderful stories, facts, speeches and visuals I could enjoy on our Echo Show.  There's so much engaging information, wonderfully organized, great sound effects!  I look forward to the day this Skill is available in schools.

title: Has potential, but still buggy
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 13, 2019
content: Multiple choice answers should have choices. I got one where I had to guess what *wasn't* a part of the circulatory system, with no choices. Compared to the world in general, very few things are actually a part of the circulatory system. (For the record, the answer she wanted was stomach, and not chickens or nose.)Also, true/false questions should be true/false not a random other word.She seemed to understand me okay, but it's hard to understand her a bit, especially on the more obscure science questions. I didn't try math or vocabulary. I have a feeling that hard vocabulary could be a problem, especially for a kid or someone who is using the game to learn English.

title: Great app but needs work
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 3, 2017
content: The application misinterpreted the correct answer to several questions. Repeated my answer that was correct. Yet,stated it was wrong. This only happens occasionally about 1/3 of the time. While this doesn't effect me. It discourages children who are looking for praise.

title: Needs improvement
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 26, 2017
content: A good idea, but it needs improvements. It does not have multiple answers programmed for correct answers. For example I responded with the word cranium instead of skull. Clearly these are the same answer. A student is more likely to use the former since that is what one is taught on class.

title: otherwise challenging and enjoyable
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 1, 2019
content: I agree with the reviewer who said enunciate, enunciate, enunciate. I would add that in the synonym antonym game, the second word is pronounced as if its first syllable were and. For example, "lazy andenergetic." Finally, for a correct response I would prefer a simple "right" or "correct," rather than a monotone "yippee," or canned cheering. Otherwise, this game is challenging and enjoyable.

title: Could use some improvement.
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 20, 2017
content: Only a limited number of questions, many times they repeat themselves and a few times they have answers that have both optional answers that are either both wrong or both correct (Examples below). I also experienced some issues similar to others with the pronunciation and speed.1."Another name for a tidal wave is a Tsunami. True or False? -Oh! I heard true but the correct answer is Tsunami." (?)2."Oops! Wrong answer. I heard Adam but the correct answer is Atom." (that's just annoying)3."Is an Albatross. a sea bird or an animal?" (both)4."Which organ purifies blood? Brain or Heart?" (neither)5."Which of the following does NOT travel in a vacuum? Radio Waves or Sound Waves?" - (both can - although sound waves require special circumstances. It gives the 'correct' answer as Radio Waves)6."Sunlight is colorless. True or false? Sorry. I heard false but the correct answer is plaque ." (?)That being said this is still worth getting if you like trivia - one of the better trivia game i've tried so far out of the general ones i've played (about 3-4 others) and some of the responses/questions are pretty good.

title: Science Wizard tries to do a lot and gets some of it right but needs retooled.
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 22, 2018
content: Besides using the skill for the first time the introduction is pretty long and should be shorten up a bit after the first couple uses. People will stop using your skill if the intro is too long and keeps repeating itself. Use session states in order to switch up the intro or you could pull different intros from an array instead of the same one, variety is key. Keep it fresh. This skill cover four major areas which are science quizzes, debate prompts, thought experiments and scientific formula. You can also learn about Physics, Chemistry and Biology. The skill did have some issues understanding my commands and I found that if you say experiment it will work, but if you say experiments the skill says that it does not understand and closes. I was finally able to get the experiments to work after 30 minutes. The debate function is pretty cool and works fine, but the quiz function will end the skill if you get a question wrong, yes just one question. The developer does provide a detailed explanation which also has links to YouTube videos. I would suggest maybe uploading those to S3 and have them play as their help function.  This skill does use skill cards for the scientific formulas, which is pretty cool.  As I said before this skill could be okay if it was retooled, but in its current state I would not enable it and only give it a half of thumb up.

content: This is a review of Amazon Echo's Skill Set.You either love cats or not. This is a cat fact finder for cat lovers, so get over it or move on. This  cat fact is very informative. The cat facts are quite unique and would be a perfect category for the family. Children love to learn and introducing them to this feature will be a good thing for them, indeed. The entire family can listen, and then discuss the fact.This is a simple category that anyone can use. If your child understands the Alexa Amazon Echo, this can be a great learning tool. title: Fun and rather random
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 5, 2015
content: One of the weirdest things I ever came across was a web site devoted to Cat Facts... on Darknet. Here is this clandestine, cloak and dagger platform, frequented by hacktivists,  handlers of illicit goods, (and the odd Ethical Hacker such as myself) and bang! A website about cats. It just goes to show that cats really do get everyone on the Internet. So why not on The Echo?Ease of Use: 5 out of 5. You ask it for a fact about cats, it tells you one. It doesn't get simpler than that. There isn't much to it, but there doesn't need to be. (Asking it to say "Meow" is a nice touch, though.)Usefulness: 4 out of 5. If you have no interest in cats, then just forget it. Me, I love cats. And, yeah, I know the API used to back this is public, but it did end up telling me things I didn't know despite my infatuation for the furry beasts. (One of which is clawing me for attention as I write this!) So I have to give a thumbs up for that.Novelty: 3 out of 5. I should have expected this, but I didn't. It is a format that would let you turn any listicle into an app. It might have been more interesting to see it grown into a general front end for listicles. Cute icon, though.Overall: 4 out of 5. Cat Facts is fun and rather random. I'm going to keep it enabled to lighten up my day during boring moments.

title: Useful Interview Prep Tool
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 2, 2022
content: I am grateful to have found an app that can help me prepare for the interview process which is often nerve-wracking.  Currently I am using still using Prepfit during my Job/Interview practice search.  The app has provided some helpful tips that has made me feel less alone during this process. It somehow manages to provide some insight into how the mind of an interviewer works.  One way it does this is by presenting the same interview question in similar ways. This helps to hone one's approach. Another thing I found helpful was how easy to use the app is inspite it's constrictions to Alexa's voice interface.  In future updates I would like to see an expansion of question categories and possibly a feature where one could record themselves to revist/score answers.

title: Very helpful in prep for interviews
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 9, 2021
content: Wanted to be able to practice my job interview skills for some recent opportunities, especially after 8 years at the same company and not having to formally interview for a while. title: Good. IMHO could use some tweaks
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 7, 2018
content: I have been auditing Medicare in different roles for 22 years, so of course I pay careful attention to the wording of the questions and answers. I think some of the questions could use more specificity. For example, there is a question about which part of Medicare pays for outpatient care. Both Part B and Part C are in the list of answers. Since B was on the list, I know the answer you want is Part B, but since Part B is included in Part C, part C also pays for outpatient. If I was a bene, I might think , 'oh no, I cant enroll in Part C, they dont pay for outpatient'.Also, there is a question about what is the definition of a SEP, the answer in the list is something about continuing to work for an EGHP. This is an example not a definition.I really like this, I play it every day. I dont think anyone has enough brain cells to remember all of the Medicare rules and definitions, but in my opinion, every once in awhile, not often, the wording of the questions could be better. Great job.

skillname: Word of the Day Flash Briefing
title: Online archive needed
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 1, 2019
content: This program has many strengths, but they sorely need some sort of online system that keeps up with words and definitions. It is very unlikely that hearing a new word once will register it permanently, but I think many WOTD fans would appreciate having an online list to which they can refer back. I've made this request a couple of times back in the early days, when WOTD was under different ownership, and shortly afterwards. No response, though. As it is, it is mildly entertaining and may reinforce words we already know, but can't teach anything unless we are sitting with pen in hand writing down what it says. Five stars will be awarded when there is an online reference that contains the words already used.

content: I've been trying my best to give the new host a good listen and a complete opportunity to grip me, but still find myself longing for the previous host. Plus, there is a word of the day quiz that you can use later in your day to recap.I will say, they are actively working out some changes (to spell twice or not, to add etymology or not, etc.) and they have an active/ responsive facebook group that they source for their insight. skillname: Word of the Day Flash Briefing
title: love!
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 19, 2018
content: 9/30/18 - UPDATEI'm updating my rating from 4 to 5 stars and I just need to say this to the Developers - y'all are really doing a great job! I say this because I recently added another word of the day skill for my flash briefing by Paul Eden because I love learning new words. I was going to add it to my flash briefing not replace your skill. Anyhoo.. After listening to it one time in my flash briefing, I immediately disabled it! The reason I disabled it was because they did not use a human being's voice, like ya'll do. Instead, they used Alexa's voice and she spoke so fast I could barely understand what she was saying! They have the same basic concept as y'all where they give the origin and different uses of the word and examples in sentences, etc.. I say that - but the truth is they spoke so fast that I don't honestly know what they really said! LOL! I don't think that Alexa gave a millisecond in between word, definition, usage, origin, etc for listener to even recognize - much less contemplate - what had been said! So kudos to you guys! Seriously! I really mean that.. You have really taken the time and listened to listeners feedback and adjusted the skill accordingly. That has paid off, in my opinion and y'all -  by far - exceed that other word of the day skill! I will stick with my Volley Word of the Day skill and be perfectly content! So thank you! Thank you for making this a skill that feels human and like you care what your listeners think! Oh.. PS I'm envious that Kate from Every Day Positivity got to be the guest host on Word of the Day and I didn't! Sad face. JK.. I have her skill in my flash briefing also and I love her! I love her cute little British accent and her super happy, positive attitude! But I am bummed I missed out on being the guest host. another sad faceORIGINAL REVIEW -Like learning new word every day and host is humorous and makes you understand the oftentimes really obscure word.

skillname: Word of the Day Flash Briefing
title: Useless for vocabulary building
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 31, 2022
content: You would think the word of the day would be a word that is uncommon, one that you don't know the meaning of, maybe a word someone uses or you read in print and you head for the web to see how it is used, and add to your vocabulary because it will work in everday speech, and is heard every so often. But obscure/archaic words you would NEVER use in speech?  Words you've NEVER heard in your lifetime, hearing them for the first time on this app?  That's what this app has evolved to, and as such it serves no purpose other than to explain an obscure word, and then never to be heard again by you or anyone you know.

skillname: Word of the Day Flash Briefing
title: Learning is a daily pursuit.
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 21, 2019

date: Reviewed in the United States on July 25, 2017

The narrator has a dry sense of humor which makes the definitions he presents very entertaining. Recommended!

skillname: Word of the Day Flash Briefing
title: Great way to learn new words
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 7, 2018
content: This is a great Alexa Skill.  As some of the Skills I‚Äôve tried are glitchy, have ads, or are not top quality, this one really stands out.  This Skill involves a guy, with a wonderful voice and style of presentation, who teaches one new word each day.  He does it in an interesting manner including spelling, usage of the word in a sentence, and a bit of humor.Also, because it‚Äôs in Flash Briefing format, it can be included in an Alexa routine.  This means if you like to set up an Alexa routine that includes weather, traffic, news, and/or a new word for the day, you can do so with this.  Were it a non-Flash Briefing, it would not be possible, as of this date, to include it in a routine.

skillname: Word of the Day Flash Briefing
title: A fun way to start my day
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 12, 2018
content: I'm a logophile, so I enjoy starting my day with a new word. But I prefer words that, although a bit unusual, are words that should be known. Examples of such words would be laconic, loquacious, rapacious, nefarious, sentient, credulous, pedantic. But the Word of the Day Flash Briefing only seems to present words that are so esoteric that you would not even see them in a scholarly journal. For example, today's word was Cicerone. Come on, how often have you seen that word? Personally, I've never seen it. That said, I always look forward to the word of the day flash briefing.

date: Reviewed in the United States on November 4, 2018
content: We listen every morning. I set it to play as a routine to make it automatic. Then we try to use the word throughout the day. My daughter likes it. My only recommendation would be that the sentences they come up with to demonstrate the word in use could be better, but that's all. Very nice app. I look forward to it in the morning.

title: I disagree with all negative reviews

content: The narrator of this skill does not come across as condescending or pretentious as other reviews suggest. Nor have I had any issue concerning the narrator's utterance of the word "Alexa". skillname: Word of the Day Flash Briefing
title: Well constructed, but words are often too esoteric
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 21, 2019
content: Most are words you have never heard before and will never hear (or use) again.  It would be better to use words like esoteric--words that we don't use often, but ARE in use and it's important to understand the meaning and use.  Also, they give the etymology (another word they could/should use) of the word, that usually is not particularly helpful. The example sentences used are often highly stilted and not a true actual context.

skillname: Word of the Day Flash Briefing
title: Words Matter
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 8, 2021
content: Today‚Äôs word of the day was ‚Äúpunditocracy‚Äù.  The example referenced a campaign that the punditocracy predicted would lose the election in a landslide. The candidate said he would demand a recount after the election. Given the current sensitive political atmosphere, low faith in elections and election results, ongoing misinformation about past and upcoming elections and threats of political violence, this was VERY irresponsible of the WOTD writers/editors. I was shocked a program that heralds words was so careless. This normalizes the idea that any election should be questioned & challenged if you don‚Äôt like the outcome. Faith in elections and election results is the bedrock of democracy. Please do better.

skillname: Word of the Day Flash Briefing

date: Reviewed in the United States on February 21, 2019
content: Our family loves the word of the day 'show' application via our Echo Show 2nd gen.  So glad it was offered as an option for the daily 'flash'. Our kids, and US, love learning new words and have a family challenge to use the word at least one time during our day.  Kuddos Word of the Day team as this 'show' is very cool.Best, The Bruder's - Las Cruces, NM

date: Reviewed in the United States on November 8, 2018
content: I've been enjoying word-of-the-day as part of my morning flash briefing for quite some time now. It's a great way to painlessly expand my vocabulary. The word choices have also gotten better so I am much more likely to use them. Bravo!

title: Informative without being stale and dry
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 30, 2018
content: I tried this on a whim and listen to it in the morning with other news feeds while I prepare for the day.  I have to say that I'm not very patient and easily irritated first thing in the morning.....ok, I'm grouchy.  But, this guy always puts a smile on my face.  He's very innovative with his word description and use in common, everyday speech.  While most of the words are not used in common speech, at least not my speech, I am hopeful that if I do run across some of the uncommon words during the course of my life that I will have some idea of their meaning and pronunciation.  I kind of doubt that I'll have much retention but I still like to try.

skillname: Word of the Day Flash Briefing
title: " An utter waste of time
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 19, 2018
content: I am a fairly educated person with an advanced degree who often scores 100% on vocabulary tests such as the one offered monthly in the "Readers Digest" magazine.  The word of the day is often a word that I have never heard and will probably never hear again.  Particularly disturbing is the sequence by the very arrogant sounding man who delivers Peppercorn Media's word of the day.  He always elicits the same feeling from me.  I want to yell out, "ALEXA STOP!"  An utter waste of time. He has totally worn out the line, "When I was a spy...."  As an aside, the feature would be quite useful if words were used that many people often hear but are not sure what the meaning of the word is.  Examples would be the typical types of words often used on the SAT exam.  Please get ride of the obnoxious purveyor of Peppercorn Media" Word of the Day - he is one of the most obnoxious people on the planet and makes me want to skip the flash briefing just to avoid him.

title: Best of the fact based apps
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 3, 2017
content: I tried it today. Not bad. Much better than the other facts based apps. Most facts based apps only give you a one line response. But not this one. I like that it is interactive and you can carry on quite a long session if you like. I learned quite a few things about animals, such as cats makes 100's of sounds but dogs only 10 sounds. Interesting. This would be a great app for someone trying to decide what animal to get for a pet. I can see myself asking Animal Advisor the next time I encounter an animal that I am not familiar with.  I tried several random animals like zebra, rats, black widow, cock roach, etc. All worked fine. I like that it gives you advice on what to do for some pests. This would be 5 stars if I can hear the animal sound, as well as see it on the new Echo Show.

date: Reviewed in the United States on January 7, 2017
content: This is an information only skill.  It does not read books to you.  It only tells you who the book was written by, when it was published, avg rating on goodreads.com and when prompted will tell you what the book is about.  Could be useful I suppose.  I kept trying to ask what the top ten books were (by rating?), to no avail.  That would be a nice feature. Or the NYT best seller list.  Would be a far more useful skill with more options.  Random book selector by genre with a such and such star rating, children books added this week (today), is such and such book appropriate for preschoolers, add such and such book to my Amazon cart or even audible, etc.  Has loads of potential, but as is seems kinda bland.

content: App was incredibly repetitious.  "The flowers of the mango tree are small and white with 5 petals and the fruit takes between 3 and 6 months to ripen.  Do you want more facts?" "yes". Repeat 6 times.  Finally started mixing the facts up after that, but then it told me about the height of the evergreen mango tree 5 times in a row.Pete and Repeat were sitting on a fence. Pete fell off. Who was left? Repeat. Pete and Repeat were sitting on a fence. Pete fell off.  Who was left? Repeat.I suppose if you are trying to memorize the facts, repetition is good, but if you just want facts for entertainment, this will probably frustrate you.

title: THE WONDERFUL ANSWER TO MY PRAYER!
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 26, 2021
content: Two of my younger, non-Witness, sisters gave me an Alexa Dot as a gift . I thought: "Have it play some of our songs from jw.org." It did - twice. Then no - because it didn't recognize the website name as a radio station. Sigh. Lots of frustration. I asked Jehovah to help me figure this out. Meanwhile, I stopped using Alexa. Then about 15 minutes ago I was downloading the Saturday afternoon sessions for the Regional Convention to my PC to have ready for Sunday. While I waited, I decided to look at the videos for the 2019 convention. And somehow saw a reference to Alexa - and setting it up to access jw.org! Came over, enabled this software for my Dot. And I'm listening to the original songs as I write this review! Our God Jehovah answers even the prayers for help in mundane things, prayers that are in harmony with his will. So yes, my brothers and sisters, get this! And PS- my thanks to the ones that made this possible.

title: Hate the content but the skill works correctly and saves me a lot of difficulty
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 23, 2021
content: I am medical caregiving in my home for a family member who is lifelong indoctrinated in this religion and gets very anxious and afraid if he can't hear the required programming.  He gets very concerned he will get in trouble if he doesn't "keep up with it".  Personally, I strongly disapprove,  and can't bring myself to participate by reading to him what I feel to be very harmful and negative material.  However, because I love him dearly and he doesn't need yet more to be upset and frightened about in his life, I added this skill to make things easier on us both.  Now he can listen to whatever he wants on it in his room, and it relieves his nerves and conscience, whereas I don't have to listen to it or directly provide it to him, which relieves my nerves and conscience.  The skill has worked correctly since I enabled it and I have had to do very little to help him with it, which works best for both of us.

title: a bridge between life and faith, an elegant solution to an age-old problem
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 2, 2018
content: The older I get the more it seems this life and the next begin to contradict one another-- be it our fast paced jobs, demanding lives, social pressures. It's getting harder to find the tools that bring faith to the forefront with ease. I learned about this Alexa skill at a friend's place and immediately showed it to my sister once we were together again. We sat in silence as the sound filled the room. I haven't felt as engrossed in mercy in a long time, and in such a simple way. It's the perfect addition for the quiet days and an even better break from the chaos on the rough ones. I'd recommend this to anyone who's looking for a little bit of God, a little bit of peace, even a few moments a day of understanding, in their lives. An elegant way to be mindful, explore, and honor the quran. The baraka is spreading. A thousand blessings on the person who made this and I look forward to incorporating it into my life.

title: This is so GREAT!!!!
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 8, 2019
content: I heard about Bamboo Books through a friend and thought it was an interesting concept.  My daughter is dyslexic and struggles with reading and actually absorbing what she is reading.  I went on and tried it out for myself and loved it.  Turns out, I can use it, too!  It plays passages from various books and then asks questions about what was just read to you.  I found it easy to use and it was good at directing my focus once I understood how it worked.  I can't wait to do this with my children.  I am sure they will love it, too!

title: Love that this provides such an easy way to practice listening
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 13, 2020
content: Outside of me reading to my kids myself, this app is the next best thing. When I'm making breakfast or getting a little work done, it feels like this app turns the kitchen into a mini neighborhood library. And I love that they can do something they like--talk with Alexa--and it gets them to actively listen and engage. I know this makes me sound old, but so many digital distractions seem designed to help kids disengage. Also, the book options are great.

title: Win-Win!
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 16, 2020
content: This has been an incredible addition to our media-based kiddo life. I often struggle at that intersection of passive/distraction and active/engaging entertainment and found this to be the latter. My five-year-old loves it, and I feel good about it - win-win!

title: Good learning tool to keep kids reading
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 24, 2019
content: Our kids have enjoyed listening and reading along, especially at bed time or when they're feeling tired. It's especially helpful if one of them has read the book already. Then, they listen/read along and get more out of it - or discover what they missed in the first reading. It's something they can do on their own, but we also like to read with them and share the story. It's a good addition to our home library.

title: Native speakers help this app excel over the Alexa speaking apps
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 18, 2017
content: I've used other apps to give me phrases in Japanese, however, these other apps have Alexa read the phrase which is worse than fingernails dragging down a chalkboard.  When I ask Translated to say something in Japanese, I get a recording of a native speaker saying it - not Alexa!  I haven't run into any problems yet!

title: Very useful and accurate.
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 26, 2017
content: Of course, I can't speak for Alexa's accuracy in all languages included in this skill.  Just French, Spanish, Italian, and basic very basic Russian and Norwegian.  She gets high marks from me in all of these.  If you are preparing to entertain a new friend or client who is not a native English speaker, this skill can help you learn a few basic phrases to help set your guest at ease and demonstrate your own openness and desire to at least try to cross the language bridge.  In that respect, you'd be surprised how little efforts on your part can yield such large results in establishing rapport and understanding.  Seen in this light, this unique and capable skill is a real boon.That's just one way I intend to use this skill.  I'm sure others will occur to me by and by.  It would be great if it went the other way, foreign-to-English, but that's very much more of a complex endeavor.Which leads me to comment on some of the negative reviews this skill has received.  To those reviewers, I ask, what were you expecting?  Berlitz in a box?  Alexa is a user-programmable device (read "savvy user" here), not a steel-plated United Nations employee.  Perhaps I should ask what some of these reviewers were smoking?In every way, this skill demonstrates some of the best things that can be done with the Alexa Skills Kit, the toolbox you use to develop skills, and it's clear from the user reviews of other skills in this category that Translated is out ahead of the pack.  The developer, and the skill, deserve a "bravo" for a job well done.  Magnifique!P.S.  I am not an employee of Amazon, nor associated in any way with the developer of this skill.

title: So helpful!
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 13, 2019

title: Perfect for DIRECT translations of words!
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 29, 2017
content: It gives the exactly translation for the words you use back, and this is fine if you can remember it. I love it, although I am a bit confused about people using it to LEARN a language... why would you do use this to learn a language? It is a direct translator for communication, not a teacher of how to speak another language!  Keep that in mind, and be aware of how improper sentence structure can sometimes really screw up the phrase you are trying to get translated.

title: Would be 2 stars higher if it didn't ask me for a review all the time!
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 20, 2017
content: Good app. Seems useful although I don't quite trust the translations 100%. Seems to take everything literally. Asked for "burp" in French and got "Exprimer le gaz" ("express the gas") or something like that. Maybe it needs some help with slang/irregular language?My main complaint & reason for the 2-star review is that every other time I close the app it begs for a review. "If you enjoyed using Translated..." NO. I don't want to be reminded of this constantly! I don't know if the act of leaving this review will stop that prompt but either way, it's a crappy thing to do. I don't want to listen to Alexa lecture me about leaving reviews and sometimes, I just want to get a word quietly and move on with my life. Now I need to tell Alexa to "stop" and that makes me (a) less likely to use the app; and (b) more likely to come leave a less-than-stellar review.

title: Gets Most Things Wrong
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2017
content: Too often says "I can't pronounce it, so I've sent the answer to your Alexa app."  The phrase in quotes dutifully pops up on my Fire tablet,  BUT, the answer (the translated word) isn't there.With other attempts the skill acts confused.  I may say "translate 'politics' into Spanish" and the skill will ask me what language.  So I tell it "Spanish." And then it will repeat the last thing I wanted translated, not the new word or phrase.  In this case, the last thing I asked for was "hello in Spanish" - which I thought would yield "hola" but instead got me "hola en Espanol."  So when the skill finally gave me the translation for "politics" what I got was "hola en Espanol."

title: Delaware County Library Events
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 14, 2017
content: A very informative schedule of events. It would be helpful if the daily hours are available for the library, along with events times. That being said:1. Why does Alexa say 'R' after stating the time in the events details?2. When there are multiple events at one location on the same day, I do not like to have to listen to all of the details for each event. For example, if I am interested in the last event of the day, I have to listen to the details for each prior event first. I would like to be able to say which event I am interested in and hear only the details for that event.

title: Very Helpful
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 1, 2021
content: Very helpful.  Words are repeated in English then in a Spanish.  Then simple sentences are repeated in Spanish several times and then you are asked to repeat the new Spanish words in a basic sentence.  Somewhat fast paced, but intensive teaching of  Spanish words and Spanish word usage in sentences.  I lived in Spain for 18 months decades ago as an English speaker.  I find this program challenging, realistic, intensive, and rewarding.  If you put in the time and effort to use and to meet the challenges if this  program,  you should find it very rewarding.  Best wishes! :)

title: Fun & Challenging!
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 26, 2021
content: This is my favorite math game so far. I was looking for something that challenges my brain a little, just to keep it active! I wish there were a few more challenges because it does get repetitive. Also, it does not recognize correct answers that are numbers of more than 3 digits. You say the right answer and it confirms but scores it as incorrect. This is ANY answer with 4 or more digits. Luckily you receive "lifelines" any time you play more than once so you can use those in order to not lose your streak.

title: Appropriate game play for elementary school ages. Allows player to name and raise a baby panda.
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 31, 2018
content: This fun, interactive game begins by introducing you to the Panda Sanctuary in Wolong, and explains that as a volunteer you must help raise a baby panda to be released in the wild. Throughout the game, the single player proceeds through levels and earns points for correct answers that lead to a healthy and happy adult panda. The player is first introduced to a companion, Ivy, who is also a volunteer. Ivy appears repeatedly to deliver advice, facts, or to help game play.The player starts with a newborn and gets to choose whether it is male or female, and then gets to name the panda. Correct answers and decisions result in the panda learning a crucial life skill. After completing each level, the player chooses whether to continue or come back tomorrow. After 9 levels of play, the baby panda has fully grown and has all of the skills it needs to be released into the wild.If the player doesn't answer the questions correctly, a Sanctuary Officer appears and gives a three-question quiz. We encountered a bit of a glitch during this section as the questions repeated, but the "correct" answers differed in two turns. Not answering the questions correctly leads to the Sanctuary Officer giving you one caution. Three cautions will cost you the game.Instant feedback on answers is given with a combination of a tone and verbal acknowledgement. Point totals are given after each question, as well as at the completion of each level. Remediation isn't consistent, but when offered, is in the form of a hint rather than explicitly giving the right answer.  Playing the game all the way through takes around 45 minutes, so for smaller children this might be better broken into a daily game time.

title: Love it - great immersive experience, well written & performed
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 19, 2021
content: We love this skill.  My 6 year old uses it everyday to save the Panda, Turtle and Tiger.  It has engaging actors and sounds effects that make it seem "real".  The choice options are given simply so you don't run into the fuzzy language issues (so my kid isn't screaming "the bamboo" at Alexa 7 times when it wants "bamboo plant." like other skills we have issues with) It also has chapters so you can pause play.  AND it remember where you stopped so you can start it again later.  Very helpful when you have a kid who loves it but needs to do other things once and a while :DAlso - we never paid or were asked to pay for extra sessions - they were all there (Turtle, Panda, Tiger) once I enabled the skill.To the developers: you asked for suggestions for other animals - my son's request: cheetahs, elephants and whales

title: Fun and engaging experience for 7-10 year olds
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 2, 2018
content: The game takes you through raising a baby panda until it is ready to be released into the wild. The narration and audio complement each other really well and create an immersive environment, with sound effects of the refuge and the forest. You can even hear your baby panda playing. I learned a lot about pandas, and the knowledge I gained is going to stick, because they were talking about my own personal baby panda. Unlike other voice-enabled stories, this one is very straightforward, and any child over the age of 6-7 will have no problem navigating through it.This is a really lovely, gentle game for kids!

title: Entertaining for older kids and parents as well.
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 19, 2018
content: I'd love to give this five stars and I hope soon I can... as I know this is a new product.Here are the reasons its only 4. *grins*Many times questions are answered correctly by the player and they are told wrong, and given the answer just given. OR. Asked same question again, answered correctly again, called faulty again. We would even be careful of how we said it.There is no way to just pause this game. It is either a total focus, or a you have to reopen the game. Any pause kicks you out. And plays the "please review." which I am glad to hear, so I review. But not glad to be kicked out when I need to talk to my kid. Or ask him to do something. A total pause would be AWESOME.  You could even end it with a please review or some such.Ivy baby talks.I would hate my toddler to be learning baby talk from something teaching them.And we Quickly found it annoying.My 10 yo started this game, we've been anxious for fun games on Alexa, and me the 12 yo joined in. Both of my sons found this game fun and cute.  And both would like more levels. So would I. this is adorable.I would love it if you would PLEASE give us multiple accounts? So that we could each raise one.It was very cute and taught all of us a lot about Panda's and I'd love to see more games likeThe over all is that this is an awesome game for this early in development. Please expand more and I can't wait for updates.

content: I liked this in my flash briefing for today in history. It will get deleted if there's another story of "what happened this week with Taylor Swift" or "we don't like Trump".Please keep it to history, not politics or entertainment.

title: What does Taylor Swift's current political opinion have to do with history?
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 10, 2018
content: Historical events are what I expect to hear covered in this flash briefing.  Not current affairs.  Not political editorializing based upon opinions.  Taylor Swift's opinions on politics belong in either an entertainment or editorial page platform, not this skill.  And putting unproven allegations of wrongdoing forward as if they were proven fact is a disturbing use of the platform.  Again, put it on the editorial page, but not in the context of a historical fact report.  Context matters.

title: Seriously?! You got political today?!!
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 10, 2018
content: I subscribed to get history, not political propeganda. I am removing you from my flash briefing.  Extremely disappointed!

content: What happened to the narrated version of this?! Now I get Alexa telling me one event followed by several annoying questions. Fire the person responcible for setting this once enjoyable skill and feature back in time to  mediocrity and return the nice lady who gave us 5 to 6 events per day with no questions.

title: Too many ads
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 16, 2020
content: I‚Äôve used this skill for over a year and I‚Äôve mostly enjoyed it. Unfortunately, over the last several months, the ads and self promo have taken over the skill. I understand the need to make money and cross promote other revenue streams, but you can‚Äôt do both every single day and expect to keep users. I have a short flash briefing on purpose and when over half of it is taken up by this single skill, it has to go.The history contet is interesing, if not always accurate (Kurt Cobain did NOT die in 2004) but it does get repetative, with the same bits repeated each year. I know the same stuff happened on the same day each year, but they could highlight a different story each year to offer some variety.All in all, I don‚Äôt recommend installing this skill unless you like commericals for toothbrushes and other podcasts.

title: Fun and Informative
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 31, 2017
content: This skill is great to have when waking up in the morning and wanting to start your day off with a little bit of knowledge! It plays every time and talks about some pretty cool stuff. My only complaint is that I wish there was more information provided. I know that more then one event has happened on a single day. If they continue to expand and update this could become a must have skill.

title: was good until a few months ago
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 23, 2020
content: They're trying to hard to promote this week in history they tag on (the same week's) excerpt at the end. title: Questions well designed, Skill is not.
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 26, 2017
content: The questions themselves are great. It is free response, and keeps score. However, it asks you 5 questions and shuts down. If you want more than 5, you have to start over from the beginning, listening to the instructions over and over again. It requires a lot of patience to wait through it.It also could have a more efficient format for the questions. Being told, "That answer is correct," and given my score after every response irritates me. It would be better if it beeped or buzzed and moved onz giving you your score at the end. After all, it is not helpful, and it isn't hard to keep track of a score when there are only 5 questions. It would qlso be nice if it gave you time to answer or a time limit. As it is set up, it asks you the question over after only a few seocnds. If we are allowed to take our time, we should also be allowed to think without such an annoying interruption.

title: What used to work is now a disaster
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 6, 2020
content: This used to be great for my autistic son we could ask ‚Äúplay (animal) sounds‚Äù or ‚Äúwhat sound does an (animal) make?‚Äù And Alexa would play the sound he was looking for. Now we dread when he wants to use this app because it doesn‚Äôt just play the animal sound it goes through a list of animals or makes an airplane noise that he has an aversion to when ‚Äúflying‚Äù to where the animal is from. When Alexa does not play the animal sound as it used to he typically is distressed and enacts self injurious behavior. This was something simple and fun for kids where they could name an animal and ask for the sound, now it‚Äôs a headache every time.

title: Great Skill with a Major Drawback

content: This skill has some really wonderful features - the parameters you can set, the fact that she'll repeat a question if it's not answered, all of it.Unfortunately, its voice recognition seems decidedly more persnikkity than that with both native apps and the other skills we've tried. At first, I thought it was an issue with my 3rd grader's still-childlike voice, but she often doesn't register my answers, either.I'm not sure how much the developer's code can impact this, but it does seem like something is off. If this can be improved, this will be a 5-star skill.

date: Reviewed in the United States on June 1, 2018
content: What a breath of fresh air this was. The music felt nostalgic but I really appreciated the explanation of how it is customary to stand, face the flag and hold your right hand over your heart when reciting to show respect for the flag. BRAVO. Our kids need to be taught this again in school. I also liked how it teaches the pledge phrase by phrase. This would be great fun for school teachers to have this in their class and let the kids take turns each day to invoke Alexa for the pledge.

skillname: Kids Word of the Day Flash Briefing
title: Still liking this skill... because the developers listened to feedback
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 14, 2018
content: UPDATE:  I'm pleased to report the developers are listening to user feedback. It is easier to listen to and self-contained for listeners who may not tune in every single day.  We complained when we couldn't understand the hosts, and they cleared it up.  We complained when they removed the spelling, and they added it back in.  Kudos to Volley for trying to give users what they want.  My original review is belowA long-time listener to the grown-up WOTD version, I was quick to add the kids' version when it launched.  While at first I felt the show was just a bit long with the riddle and pun-filled characters, I soon realized that charm was just what kids need to activate their brains and get focused.  What really impressed me though is the mnemonic aids built in to the broadcast that will subtly assist them in remembering the word itself: repetition is obvious, but the use of a musical scale during the spelling portion to chunk large data and sequence it?  That's genius.  Now if I could just find a way to play just this briefing instead of the whole flash update when I want to share it with my classroom this fall, I'd be all set!

skillname: Kids Word of the Day Flash Briefing
title: It WAS great
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2018
content: I used to enjoy their program but I believe they stopped their production. They kept repeating the same old episodes over and over, so I finally deleted them from my briefing.> Original Review <I love love love this flash briefing! I‚Äôm an adult and English is not my first language. I‚Äôve been looking for English learning skills/flash briefings but I haven‚Äôt found anything that made me want to stick with. This one is short, fun and very useful.I took a star off because... 1. Please spell out the word. I believe it‚Äôs very important. 2. Although I love that you bring in special guests, many of them mumble and I don‚Äôt understand them. Because this show is for learning, I hope the guests could speak out a bit more clearly.With those improvements, this show can easily get 100 stars! Also, please consider developing a kids idiom of the day flash briefing. I think you can make another funny show. ‚ÄúCold turkey? Whaaat??‚Äù

skillname: Kids Word of the Day Flash Briefing
title: No more incomprehensible voices! Yay!
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 15, 2018
content: We listen to Kids Word of the Day each morning while waiting for the bus, so the information needs to be concise.  The developers must have listened to the bad reviews because lately we haven't had any "guests".  I was considering deleting this skill, but the current format is clear and efficient, even with the time used for the riddles. The riddles are not easy and I like listening to my children discuss their guesses and reasoning behind them.

skillname: Kids Word of the Day Flash Briefing
title: Good vocabulary builder, fun, but...
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 12, 2018
content: When we began listening, Finn McCool and Marion Webster provided nice, comprehensible riddles and definitions. Over the past several weeks guest hosts such as "Bane," "Snape," and "Yoda" have been bringing us words instead. This would be great, if they didn't sound like they were speaking thru a mouth full of marbles from the bottom of the ocean. Seriously, I can't understand more than 1 word in 3. Thankfully the host repeats most definitions in a clear tone, but  I was tired of the guests three weeks ago. Even the kids (5 thru 9) are frustrated now.

title: This skill is great! It's the only one I use and honestly ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 6, 2017
content:
This skill is great! It's the only one I use and honestly the sole reason I got my Echo Dot. I am an Anthropologist who specializes in the culture and social impact that D3 technical colleges have on their communities. I.I.T. Is a unique university due to the fact that a train goes right through the middle of campus, in my research, I have concluded that this interesting design element of this historical campus leads to students here getting not only higher GPA's but also have a higher tendency to break their left wrist. Such an astonishing and beautiful campus, my research would mean NOTHING if it were not for this beautifully and thoughtfully crafted Alexa skill. Keep up the good work, Alex.Below is some of my work if anyone is interested in the ever-evolving, fast-paced world of anthropology.

Anthropology For Dummies

title: Here's all 39 listed!
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 8, 2018
content: "Alexa, open Zookeeper"......This is our toddler's favorite Skill. Alexa will ask you to say an animal, and - IF IT'S ONE OF THE 39 SHE KNOWS - she'll play its sound for you and tell you what it is. This is an excellent game for the little ones! Problems: 1) She doesn't know owl, frog, donkey, and some other key, common animals. 2) She also doesn't just give you the list of what she DOES know!But I've got your solution. We figured it out! Here's the list of all 39 ....in no particular order:1. Monkey2. Zebra3. Rhinoceros/rhino4. Hippopotamus/hippo5. Gorilla6. Elephant7. Lion8. Tiger9. Cheetah10. Bobcat11. Jaguar12. Giraffe13. Whale14. Dolphin15. Turkey/bird16. Horse17. Duck/bird18. Goose/bird19. Eagle/bird20. Raccoon21. Chimpanzee/chimp22. Cat/kitty23. Dog24. Snake25. Seal26. Pig/hog27. Fox28. Alligator/gator29. Elk30. Bear31. Rooster/chicken/bird32. Leopard33. Wolf34. Coyote35. Sheep36. Cow37. Hyena38. Penguin/bird39. Peacock/bird

title: Inconsistent
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2020
content: Like other reviewers, I've used this forever with my 2 yr old granddaughter, who loves it, for now.  No new animals have been added in ages, there are many common animal sounds missing and some of the recordings sound like the old "pull and say" toys.  Others are also right that some sounds are realistic and/or long.  Others are mechanical and super short.  Some I doubt are accurate.  My granddaughter is starting to get tired of them and I thought a new Alexa Show would SHOW pictures of the animals when it plays the sound.  Doesn't sound like that's the case.  For comparison our other "assistant" has much better animal sounds.

title: Fun for family w/ children.  Great for kids w/ speech or language delay!
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 12, 2017
content: Easy and fun to use for entire family, including speech therapist for our 2-yr-old!  It encourages our toddler to announciate animals with 1-3 syllables.I'd give it 5 stars if this skill had more than 30-something animals. Also, this skill synced animals of the same species/family. For example; Pig & Hog "oink." Chicken & Rooster "cocka-doodle-do." Bird & Duck "quack."  That can confuse kids as they may not understand that all ducks are birds, but not all birds are ducks!It does have a great variety, not just the typical barnyard and basic backyard animals! Unless you watch a lot of National Geographic, who knew what a zebra or a hippo sounded like?! Thanks to Zoo Keeper, our 2-yr-old can identify and mimic a larger variety of animals!

title: Leaves a lot to be desired
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 11, 2016
content: I literally read the example questions off the screen and Alexa could not answer them.  i did this because I saw an add for the google thing like Alexa. Alexa is looking like an inferior product compared to it's competitor. The app is a great idea, especially for kids, but it doesn't really work well.

title: Swing.... And A Miss!
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 12, 2019
content: This has the potential to be so great, but instead is about as terrible as I can imagine.Sure there are a few dozen animals to choose from, and if your google-foo is good you can find what they are, but you'l never guess them on your own.  Even common farm animals that one would expect to be present are missing: Chicken Hen anyone? No, I didn't say Rooster...Animals noises provided are poorly recorded examples, with little consistency between them.  One animal sound might be so quiet that it's barely audible, while another has so much background noise one wonders what the actual sound is.  Not to mention sample length, where one animal sound may be a 10 second recording, where another is only 2 or 3 (there doesn't seem to be any correlation to actual animal call duration).  Oh, and give the Lion a listen.  It's not the roar that 2 year olds and MGM movie fans associate with Lions, I'm not sure what it is actually.All said, it's a cool idea, and my kid enjoys it, but it was obviously put together in an afternoon by an intern that hated the assignment.I would happily spend a couple days to improve it for Amazon if able.

title: Easy way to hear what's happening at Weber State
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 24, 2017
content: I love the ability to ask and hear what's happening at Weber State University, especially Engineering. I can be typing away, listening to music, and simply ask "Ask Weber State University for the latest news." Alexa lowers the volume for my favorite BeBop station and gives me the headlines from the Facebook page. I ought to be able to do this for any of the organizations I'm interested in: the local tv and radio stations, local sports teams including my own intramural teams, my favorite restaurant's daily special, etc. Witlingo has a great system going here.

title: Best Alexa Webcam App
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 30, 2019
content: This one had no reviews - so after trying EarthCam, World Scanner, and Web Cams, I needed to leave one. This is the best webcam app out right now, hands down. You can actually scroll through the cams giving you some control over what you are seeing, and the touch and voice commands actually work. EarthCam's controls are wonky and tend to just put you back at Times Square. Web Cams is also random and displays a lot of snapshots or static pics, which don't in my mind qualify.  Get this one!

title: World scanner is annoying
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 2, 2020
content: This app would be great with just a few modifications. The order of images is fixed. Why not customizable or even random? Each image is loudly announced on the echo show and the name is chopped off halfway by Alexa. (There is one called Yecudibee, What is that?) There is no way to set up a silent Slideshow mode showing each image for 5 or 10 seconds. Instead the user has to say "Alexa Next" to advance to the next image. This is really tedious when you are in the room to hear that over and over. I know it is a free app but surely Amazon could do better.

title: Nice Little Gem for Tourists AND townies
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 27, 2019
content: If you're coming to Doylestown (D-town) Bucks County, PA and want to get a few tips as to what to do, this is a nice little app. It offers lists of museums (we sure do have a lot), restaurants which attract chefs from NYC, and beautiful local parks. Ever hear of Ringing Rocks?  You used to be able to bring a small hammer and tap a humongous rock which would make the other rocks sound like they were "ringing".  Super cool.  This app offers a help section so you can ask questions.  It features different ideas daily.  If you are local, wow, who knew how much history and fun things there was to do right in our little town!  Follow this app and put us on the map. We ARE D-town.

title: I am a homeschooler. On any given day, ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 18, 2018
content: I am a homeschooler.  On any given day, my 6 and 7 year old boys are asking me, "Mom, how do you spell xxx?  I have trained them to ask Alexa.  If it is something that is a short word, and they already have a general idea of how it it is spelled, this works.  Otherwise, they say it is too fast.  I was hoping this would spell a little bit slower, but it does not.  So far, I don't see the advantage of using this skill over simply just asking Alexa.  By the way, I prefer to spell words for them by saying each phonogram and having them fill in the letter or letters.  If you want to know more about teaching spelling or reading through phonograms, look up the program All About Spelling or All About Reading.

title: This is Not A Spell Checker
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 9, 2018
content: This app spells the word for you. I want an app that allows my kids to say a word, then spell it, then have Alexa check their spelling. Alexa would tell them correct or incorrect. After a few incorrect tries Alexa could say "do you want me to spell it for you?" This would be a true spell checker. It could help them with the spelling lists that they get from school every day.

title: Gets it wrong half the time
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 25, 2019
content: Correct answers by the listener are often not accepted, sometimes because the device didn‚Äôt ‚Äúhear‚Äù it correctly, other times because the device is looking for the wrong answer. In about five minutes, with a native German speaker listening in, we found these words given the wrong article: Stift, Lexikon, Fenster, Maus, Schaukel.  How did so many incorrect articles creep in? Were the developers too cheap to pay a fee to use a German dictionary? I suspect so. Sheer volume of mentions of ‚ÄúDie Sendung mit der Maus‚Äù might have been enough to drown out the correct ‚Äúdie Maus‚Äù if the developer was trying to program a way to define the correct articles cheaply. Also, ‚Äúder Stift‚Äù meaning pencil is not the same as ‚Äúdas Stift‚Äù meaning a trust or foundation.

skillname: Class Picker - Random picker for Teachers
title: Personalization
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 2, 2019
content: I love the class picker. It is handy that it can be customized with student names or even words for a specific activity of your choosing.  For example, I've used it for a lesson in which we were working on moods in literature.  I input multiple moods, such as frightened or angry. Then, I asked the class picker to choose one and the students would write as many words as they could think of that would create the given mood. We did several examples and it kept the students engaged. The students like it when I  use it to choose a student for a particular task. I also like that it has premade options to choose from, such as a color or a country.  So, if you need something quick, you can simply ask.

skillname: Class Picker - Random picker for Teachers
title: Wonderful!
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 16, 2019
content: Class Picker by askMyClass is a great addition to use along with an Alexa enabled device.  I was able to quickly input my students names into the Class Picker and I use it frequently to randomly pick a student's during instruction.  My kindergarteners absolutely love it!  They get so excited every time a name is selected, as Alexa changes up how she says a student's name with many different sound effects.  I also easily set up table groups that I use for calling on random table groups during cooperative learning.

skillname: Class Picker - Random picker for Teachers
title: Class Picker
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 1, 2019
content: The kids LOVE when I use AskMyClass Class Picker to randomly select a student. There is never any question about who was chosen. And the surprise on their face when they hear their name being spoken by Alexa is priceless. Much more 21st century than picking a stick from a cup, although I do that too.

skillname: Class Picker - Random picker for Teachers
title: Clever and Useful
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 1, 2019
content: This is such a clever, useful tool! As a teacher, I tend to fall into a rut with my activities and examples. It's so nice to have Class Picker as an option in my classroom. I especially like when it randomly picks children to dismiss because then I don't have to make that decision.

skillname: Class Picker - Random picker for Teachers
title: We love Class Picker!
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 26, 2019
content: The novelty of Alexa calling on students using Class Picker engages students and has them quietly listening, hoping their name will be called. They also love the random generated pickers as well, such as Alexa picking a planet or color. We love the twist this has added to our classroom!

skillname: Class Picker - Random picker for Teachers
title: Great Classroom Addtion
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 16, 2019
content: Class Picker by askMyClass is a personalized touch to the technology in your classroom. It can be used to call on students, create groups or partnerships, and maintain small group learning situations. Students love hearing the Alexa device call their names, which has always been accurate for all of my students and their unique names.

title: great skill, and great response from developers
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 8, 2019
content: I'm new to the smart home technology, but decided to start with Alexa, as I have a prime account and this made the most sense as a first assistant over google right now since I have more practical uses for the echo.  Anyway today, I enabled Bird song, and loved the bird calls it came with.  I soon found It didn't have any Macaw calls, which I was surprised about as they are well known large parrots, and to some common pets.  Anyway emailed the suggestion box, and received a response from the developers.  They went above and beyond and added quite a few Macaw calls.  Great Job guys and great skill.

title: Stream bird songs! A veritable symphony!
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 16, 2018
content: Very cool!!! As an avid birder I enjoy anything that can help me understand and/or better appreciate all of our fine feathered friends! Just learned of a very cool feature which enables you to stream a variety of bird songs! Try ""Alexa, ask Bird Song for a song stream." Bird Song will then play one bird song after another until you say "Alexa, stop." VERY cool and makes for nice background "music" while I work! Can't wait until you can set an alarm and have a bird song play!! Keep up the great work!!!

title: Wonderful Alexa skill for birdwatchers!
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 17, 2017
content: I'm playing around with my new Echo Dot and tried this skill out as we love to watch the various birds on our feeders.  We asked Alexa about American Robin, the Bald Eagle, and both came through quick and without a problem.  Alexa asked me what bird I wanted to listen to next and I said, "Big Bird!" and unexpectedly, Alexa played Big Bird's voice from Sesame Street.  All angles covered, or what?!?

title: The best thing invented for calming a screaming cockatoo.
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 12, 2019
content: I was browsing for cockatoo sounds because my screaming Moluccan cockatoo was making my morning miserable, any anyone who has experienced this cockatoo's screams knows exactly what I mean.  During my browsing I stumbled upon this Alexa  skill and enabled it. Result: immediate peaceful sounds from my cockatoo as he chirped along for hours while I blissfully did my chores. Now I will need get another Alexa device for my bird's room!

title: Better than nothing, I suppose
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 11, 2019
content: I very much liked the Audubon skill, which seems to have disappeared. I don't much like this skill. For instance, for Carolina Wren, you get the alarm call, not the song, so someone trying to ID a song they heard in their yard, or trying to confirm the song that goes with that bird, likely would be confused. It also doesn't confine its songs to American birds. For instance, when I asked for Mockingbird, I got Long Tailed Mockingbird, which is a neotropical bird that lives mostly on the Pacific coast of South America. While I knew it wasn't my backyard bird, many people would not know to ask for a Northern Mockingbird. I don't know what happened to the Audubon skill, which was MUCH better, and asking for it defaults to this skill even when this skill is not enabled. The Audubon skill would give you all calls of the bird you requested, one at a time, asking which you'd like to hear next. It wasn't perfect, but it was much better than this skill.

title: Needs some work
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 2, 2020
content: I am an intermediate level birder with beginner skills in bird calls.  This app is a great idea, but is missing on some points if it wants to help people learn the calls.  It would be helpful to be able to narrow down the calls regionally.  I tried to play the game, but was stumped by bird calls from birds located in Indonesia.  It is also missing at least one bird that is crucial:  the Willow Flycatcher.  The only way to tell the difference between the Willow Flycatcher and the Alder Flycatcher is by their song. I would love to be able to play them back to back to learn the difference.  The birds are also not properly classified in the Bird List i.e. there is a section on "yellowthroats", some of these should be warblers.  I am going to have to stick to Cornell on this one.  If improvements are made, let me know.  It has potential.
