title: Good skill and great customer service
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 12, 2019
content: When i first enabled this skill a week ago, there were several issues that made it difficult to use. i emailed the creator and he replied very quickly. We emailed back and forth several times in a short period of time and he updated the skill to fix those issues. Yes you can only have 8 words per list unless you buy the skill but you can now delete words and lists. I found it easy to add words and delete words. I love that I can now quiz my son on his spelling words without actually doing it myself!Also, when adding words that sound the same but are spelled different, I found that if you just spell the word instead of saying it, it will add correctly. There is still room for improvement but so far this is a great skill.

Even then...there was a bug on one word that no matter how close i sat to the speaker or how long i waited after the chime it would say i started too soon and put the word back into the pile. i thought the speaker maybe was picking up ambient noise but it never did that consistently on other words. i thought this would be great for my first grader but there‚Äôs no way he‚Äôd have the patience with Alexa telling him after most words that he either started too soon or she couldnt hear him. title: More applications just keep coming to mind!
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 14, 2019
content: I began with a few simple tasks triggered by my Alexa Dots.  Soon I had grown quite a nice and very useful furnace monitor program (using a WiFi Witty board) for my home furnace.  Firmware is written using Arduino IDE, and interfacing to DataHub was very easy using their triggers list and slots!It connects simply to the existing thermostat and monitors run time and duty cycle, and then computes fuel usage, cost, and generates run-time statistics.  It's not only very useful to learn more about how the furnace operation changes as does weather and thermostat settings, but is a lot of fun asking Alexa the "furnace status" throughout the day (and night!) :)Now the ideas just don't stop coming of all the things I can add voice to so simply.  I love it!!!

title: Finally I can request passages easily
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 2, 2018
content: I've tried a bunch of these apps. We used one that would read a set number of verses every day, but I always wanted to just pick a passage and have it read. This does all the LDS standard works, which is great. Alexa's pronunciation is sometimes comical. I giveit five stars just because it works. You can day "tell the scriptures to read Luke chapter 2"  and it does it. What more could I ask for? Well, I would love to have it read with a professional quality voice recording rather than using the text to speech engine. There was an app that did that, but it didn't quit work right and isn't in the skills library anymore that I can find. If that comes out, I will happily switch, but this works in the meantime.

title: Great skill but still has many bugs
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 8, 2018
content: The skill is great and does everything it should. But for some reason Alexa seems to always stop reading  before the end of a chapter if we ask her to read a whole chapter. It would also be nice to have her save your spot and continue reading from where she left off. But it's a great start.

title: Better than the Most Popular (still room to improve)
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 31, 2016
content: I think by now everybody who owns a smart phone or tablet as the Bible from You Version. I tried that on the echo and was very disappointed. Better to be used as has always. The Scriptures give you a little more flexibility without having to think too hard. I like that it will answer questions, give you random motivation or thoughts, and will read entire chapters. Still have to play with it a little more to see if it would play, for example, 1st John chapter 1 through 3? I didn't ask it to play 1st John Chapter 1, and it read the first 10 versus.People are going to get hung up over pronunciation, given the fact that it has to be compatible with so many different languages in the English-language itself is pretty tricky for most people I think she does a great job of reading a book 2000 years old.One suggestion could be to also allow the user to highlight, say, memorize key verses. But I do think that you have created a very good app (skilled) specifically for Amazon Echo.

title: Doesn't understand every book request
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 2, 2019
content: It understood my request to read 1 Corinthians 13; however, when I requested it to read Ephesians chapter 5, it couldn't understand it. It would say, "I can't find a book called 'Ee-fusions'". üòï It did successfully read Hebrews 11.I asked for something else in the Bible (can't remember what it was] and it read a few verses at the end of Alma chapter 42. Odd, but that led me to believe that it could read from "The Book of Mormon, Another Testament of Jesus Christ".So, I tried a couple of Book of Mormon books as well. It did not understand Moroni chapter 7; however, it did understand the command to read Alma chapter 5. It cut out after announcing, "Reading Alma chapter 5 verses 1 through [it then dropped out].  Didn't have time to try all of the books in The Book of Mormon at the time of those review.

title: Didn't work for me.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 19, 2016
content: Doesn't work.  "Alexa, read Doctrine and Covenants 4".  She reads Moroni 10:14.  "Alexa, read Doctrine and Covenants 4". She reads 3 Nephi 2:3.  "Alexa, read Doctrine and Covenants *Section* 4".  She reads Alma 11:5.  I'm not sure why asking the same thing over and over again not only does't result in the desired outcome, but it has different results each time.It would be nice to have voice activated scriptures, but if I can't have the app read where I want, it misses the entire point.

title: Good for dementia patients and history buffs
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 8, 2017
content: I like this skill, especially for use with family members who have dementia, and I applaud the developers for keeping the elderly in mind while developing new skills. This skill would be so much better if you could get multiple "memories" per year. As it is, there are only about 100 years available, with one memory per year. Once you run through those, you have heard everything. But it's a good start -- I would welcome the chance to amend this review when the skill is made more robust.

content: The voice is the Bookshare reader, not Alexa, but Alexa is used to access the book.It takes a LONG time to get past all the front matter, and I cannot figure out how to get Alexa to skip it. Alexa also gets stuck when I say, "no" to continue the current book. I have to exit and renter the app and ask for my booklist.I am excited about this Alexa skill! I do hope the team working on it continues to improve it, but I am VERY grateful that it was released in its Beta form. THANK YOU to everyone involved! This is a 5 star BETA, even though I would not give it 5 stars as a FINAL app.Will Astro Amazon Robot be able to read Bookshare books when he is released? Maybe we could have an Astro-sounding voice read the books to us?I am vision-impaired. My sight is deteriorating at about the same pace as new technology is being developed. Alexa reading my Bookshare books is the most exciting new tech since the announcement for Astro. Bookshare and Amazon, please please keep working together!

title: Such a fun game!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 16, 2019
content: Such a fun game!  I hadn‚Äôt played a game like this before, but it reminds me of a choose your own adventure book where the storyline is built on the fly based on the answers that you give. And, with so many different choices built in, you can play over and over, and it remains fresh and interesting. The different voices and dialogue were very clear, and the game had no problems understanding the directions that we gave it. Frankly, the stories were pretty funny, and I was surprised how much I laughed. And, they snuck in a bunch of historic details to boot to make the stories more realistic. Pretty cool! Highly recommend!

title: Works great once you know how to set it up.
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 19, 2021
content: For the topic, pick anything that will be unique. I like this better than being forced to register my email, don't you? Clever way to associate your Alexa device with your web map browser session (the URL is in the instructions). Once your topic is set, go to the web site and put in the same topic that you chose for the skill. That allows you to voice control your browser on that web site using your voice on the Echo device !Then you can do these commands:Alexa, ask Web Map to zoom in.Alexa, ask Web Map to locate a place.Alexa, ask Web Map to locate a country.Alexa, ask Web Map to reset the map.Alexa, ask Web Map to find my current location.Alexa, ask Web Map to remove all graphics.Alexa, ask Web Map to spin the globe.Alexa, ask Web Map to pause animation.Alexa, ask Web Map to buffer the point.Alexa, ask Web Map to fly over a city.Alexa, ask Web Map to start an earthquake.Alexa, ask Web Map to show hurricanes.Alexa, ask Web Map to tilt the camera.Alexa, ask Web Map to change the heading of the camera.Alexa, ask Web Map to open help.Alexa, ask Web Map to close help.Alexa, ask Web Map about a galaxy far far away.

title: Best dictionary ever
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 24, 2018
content: This dictionary works seamlessly and gives full definitions with examples in two parts - short introduction after which you can hear second part when Alexa ask you if you want to hear more. Fantastic dictionary for Alexa devices. Alexa often does not find a word after commanding her with simple ‚Äúlook up‚Äù and doing it with smart dictionary does not involve much more talking - just ‚ÄúAlexa, ask Smart dictionary for/about ...your word...‚Äù that‚Äôs it. Plus, you get really good definitions - neither too short nor too long - just fine, succinct but comprehensive, and importantly with examples - typically with ca. two examples of usage in sentences. On the negative side, and only for warning not to discard this fine skill too soon, you might experience some initial problems with it but when it's finally up and running, everything seems to go smoothly.

title: Oops, changed from 5 to 3
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 3, 2020
content: It's easier for me (70 years old) to use 'Open Smart Dictionary' and then interact via 'look up'. Being taciturn by nature, I find the 'Ask' syntax awkward and I get tongue-tied.But I do enjoy the interaction and Smart Dictionary has a better definition for 'rational number' than Alexa's default source.  [ UPDATE: After my previous good review (above), I used Smart Dictionary to confirm the definition of 'taciturn' used above. It couldn't find it, no matter how fast, slow, loud, soft I said it. I must have tried 20+ attempts (and the irony is not lost on me). Alexa's default dictionary has no problem, nor does Google Assistant. So bye-bye. ]

title: Fruit game seems like a demo to me.

content: The skill gives the same questions and fails to educate the user if they get a question wrong. It also doesn't use any SFX, it's just Alexa's Voice. skillname: Ask My Class - A Teacher's Support Tool
title: My class
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 3, 2018
content: I was able to pilot this for a few weeks. My students loved it! It has transitional music for my groups, it randomly calls on my students, it randomly calls tables, Alexa reminder is awesome. It reminds my students to go to speech, Intervention, lunch. I love it.

skillname: Ask My Class - A Teacher's Support Tool
title: AskMyClass - Fantastic Addition to Any Classroom! Game Changer!
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 1, 2019
content: Last school year I had the opportunity to pilot this program. It has been only positive! And the changes that have been made since I started have all been fantastic! A lot of thought has gone into what real students and teachers want, need, and can use in the classroom. I so appreciate the ease of use and practicality of AskMyClass. I cannot imagine teaching without it now! We use it every day during our Morning Meeting to set an intention for the day with a daily affirmation. The students remind me if we don't! It can offer ideas for a morning greeting or activity when I am needing inspiration. We love the music countdowns and transitions. The background music is just enough to add to the working environment, but not so engaging that the students are distracted. I appreciate all of the efforts to include mindfulness and growth mindset into the activities. It's like having another adult in the classroom to help. What teacher wouldn't want that! I have used a good amount of the features that AskMyClass has, but I also know there is a lot more that I need to try out. I am so glad to have had the opportunity to use it last year and this year. I cannot recommend it highly enough. One last thought, using the Amazon remote has been a great resource to help clear up any background noice when giving commands.

skillname: Ask My Class - A Teacher's Support Tool
title: A Great Teacher's Assialstant!
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 3, 2021
content: I have been using my Echo Dot and Ask My Class in my Grade 2 class for over a year now. I literally use it everyday. So much so, my students expect her to be part of the day. I really like the classroom management aspect of it and feel it's extremely helpful. From timers for portions of my lessons, to having her randomly pick a student's name, my class has really benefitted from our Echo.During free time my students have the opportunity to ask her questions. I also like it because students can use her to help with spelling and checking competed math problems. My classroom is ELL so using my echo as a tool to promote the use of English is very helpful. Its a nice motivational tool.I look forward to updates and new features to use in my class! Thanks!

skillname: Ask My Class - A Teacher's Support Tool
title: Classroom Game Changer
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 16, 2019
content: From classroom transitions to indoor recess games, askMyClass has changed my classroom for the better! This Amazon skill is an effective way to manage a classroom, review academic skills, and maintain student work all in a fun way. Build your community with the quote of the day, morning message, reflective questions and more. Incorporate sensory learning with mindful moments, dance breaks, and music countdowns. Review academic content with math word problems, writing prompts, and grammar questions. Students are able to prompt the skill for emotional regulation breaks, mindful moments, and other brain break activities. I was fortunate enough to pilot the skill in its first year and loved it so much that I was able to convince my district's tech director to purchases licenses for a full district pilot. I can not imagine my classroom without the askMyClass skill. It has enhanced my use of Alexa because I know every activity, prompt, or transition is all kid-friendly and classroom ready.

skillname: Ask My Class - A Teacher's Support Tool
title: Very Helpful!
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 28, 2019
content: I was able to pilot this skill and I am now using it in my 6th grade classroom for the second year. It's a time saver and also helps keep kids engaged.  I use it daily for our morning meeting by asking for things like a morning greeting, sharing questions, and a daily affirmation. I also use it for background music or ambient sounds. It is also possible to customize some aspects, such as having it choose students or setting up a classroom daily briefing.

skillname: Ask My Class - A Teacher's Support Tool
title: Engaging!
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 16, 2019
content: Ask My Class is an amazing tool to use for classrooms!  It has positively enhanced instruction to my kindergarten students.  I love how I can use simple commands for transitions, countdowns, story problems, calming techniques, lining up, name pickers, and so much more.  If you have an Alexa enabled device, I highly recommend Ask My Class.

skillname: Ask My Class - A Teacher's Support Tool
title: Changed my classroom!
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 2, 2019
content: AskMyClass has really made a big change in my classroom. My students are more engaged and always excited to hear what Alexa will say. They have become more careful listeners and I've even noticed a change in the voice level in my classroom. We use AskMyClass throughout the day as they help my students build 21st-century skills. We always start out each day with a daily affirmation and quote. I like that I can easily use a mindfulness activity or SEL at any moment. I really couldn't imagine my class without it! I know my students will be using voice technology in the future so I know I need to prepare them with these skills now.

skillname: Ask My Class - A Teacher's Support Tool

content: I love the idea of AskMyClass, but the setup wasn‚Äôt easy. I had to get my IT department to allow my Echo access to our network. Then, once I got everything online, the web based UI for setting up different skills within AskMyClass was very daunting.

skillname: Ask My Class - A Teacher's Support Tool
title: Like Having Another Teacher in the Room
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 1, 2019
content: It's like having another teacher in the room! I love all the ways in which AskMyClass can help me throughout my day! It's so useful!I love the fun games, the classroom management and the timer!

skillname: Ask My Class - A Teacher's Support Tool
title: Alexa-Our favorite new class member!
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 26, 2019
content: AskMyClass has not only added some novelty and variety to my classroom but structure as well. There are so many great classroom management features that are able to be used seamlessly. Students also love various games and activities that we can access-so much so that they love staying in from recess to play with Alexa. I can't imagine our classroom without AskMyClass!

date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content: This is nice in theory and I enjoy hearing the quotes, but not when many are wrongly attributed. It gave me two very well-known quotes and cited the wrong play. It said "Life's but a walking shadow, a poor player, That struts and frets his hour upon the stage, And then is heard no more," was from Much Ado, when it's from Macbeth. It said "If we shadows have offended,Think but this, and all is mended," etc was from Richard II when it's from Midsummer Night's Dream. I end up yelling at my Echo.  Hope no students are listening to it.

title: I wish the questions were harder
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 30, 2018
content: The questions are extremely basic. while that‚Äôs great for elementary school kids (not sarcasm, I really think that‚Äôs great) I wish you could select a difficulty level for adults who want to be challenged. But it is fun to see how fast you can go.  I also learned you need to only give a number. If you say the units by accident (ie. ‚Äú55 cents‚Äù instead of just ‚Äú55‚Äù) you‚Äôll get the problem wrong. At one point I said an answer and Alexa ifnores me. I had to repeat the answer over and over before she finally registered it. when you‚Äôre going for speed, the long delay was annoying. so you hear that, VA?CA would have beaten you today if my Alwxa had just listened to me!

Is there any way we ad an option for providing a confirmation when the game hears a wrong answer?2> Another way is to provide multiple choices, so that the answer is always A, B,C....3> Use the same concept and add levels. title: Valuable insight from an industry leader... Just by asking Alexa for it.
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2017
content: Having the wisdom of the CEO of a major player in the PR and Digital Marketing world accessible, simply by the sound of my voice asking for it, is amazing.  Her understanding of the marketplace, as well offering advice on being a leader/innovator is invaluable for insight into any industry. The idea of competing against transitions in the market, as opposed to the competitors themselves, is a revelation.  Her thoughts on how to correctly nurture and engage talent (‚Äúfuture workplaces‚Äù) is right on the money, and hope that other leaders will follow her examples.  The format is short and to the point, and ideal for a quick hit of inspiration/understanding when you‚Äôre on-the-go.  I look forward to future editions.

title: Fresh & insightful
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2017
content: Just heard Kathy's Thoughts on Market Trends -- great insight on competing against market transitions and not competitors. The Voice format also made for a fun break for reflection in between work deadlines, and I also listened to Kathy's Thoughts on Authentic Leaders and Future Workplaces which I found to be worthwhile. Looking forward to next week's set! (One side note: if you're new to enabling Skills on Echo, the set-up might be slightly fiddly -- but this isn't specific to Kathy's Thoughts, only the Skills function in general. Check it out!)

title: Unique skill from a PR CEO
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 15, 2017
content: This is a great skill. I like it because it's real-life observations and points of view from a PR CEO, in her voice. I haven't seen a skill like this. She discusses topics ranging from culture to authentic leadership, to competition, and more. It's also good because it's easy to use, with very simple commands. We need more like this where the brand actually speaks to you. Kudos for this effort, I look forward to updates.

title: Inspirational
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 16, 2017
content: I discovered Kathy's thoughts recently when looking for Inspirational programs on Alexa. These CEO insights put a perspective on work today and the future of work, from a leadership and change maker perspective. It is a potpourri of unique insights on creating and envisioning the workplace and the way companies need to position themselves, and what you should know to drive the change.

title: Not much fun
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 29, 2016
content: As a person who has known Morse since childhood, I was looking forward to some fun. Oh well. First of all, using the terms "dot" and "dash"'are difficult. Standard terms are ""dit" fir a dot and "dah" for a dash in spoken terms. Hearing "dot dash dot dot" caused me to have to visualize a dot and a dash. Very cumbersome. Plus, Alexa was constantly mis-hearing me, as in, I say "n" and she'd reply "that answer is wrong; the answer is n". Frustrating, and not much fun after all.

title: Educational and deeply engaging for kids
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 14, 2019
content: Since I do not have a television at home, it is sometimes difficult to keep kids engaged beyond a point (I run out of storytelling abilities after the first seven minutes or so). Last evening, my five-year-friend (neighbor) was visiting (her mother had some chores to deal with)‚Äîand after exhausting the Dr Seuss book, and a couple of stories, I turned on this new skill on impulse! It took the child a minute to get the hang of it‚Äîand she was totally engaged for the next half hour. Each passage had a bunch of questions‚Äîand the child sat there chatting patiently with ‚ÄòAlexa‚Äô‚Äîthe first time in the evening she just sat in one place and answered questions instead of asking them! When her mother arrived, she was in the middle of the skeleton costume story‚Äîand the mother was a little surprised when her daughter announced: Mamma‚Äîyou have 206 bones! Yup‚ÄîI would highly recommend this skill. Edutainment? Is that what they call it?

title: Clever idea, but badly implemented
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 26, 2019
content: I was immediately excited to try this out, having been raised on Zombo Com by a Dad with an absurd sense of humor.This skill doesn't encapsulate any of the weird magic of the original Zombo Com, though. I was hoping it would be in the original voice, sort of like an MP3. Even better if it had a spinning group of circles on the Echo Show screen, similar to the website.Nope. Alexa reads out the lines, with none of the dramatic voicing, and no pauses in between sentences. Line after line after line. If she at least paused 5-10 seconds between lines, it would be better, but color me disappointed. This skill is really only worth the internal chuckle you get when saying "Alexa, ask zombo com about zombo com".

title: anthropologist/educator
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 28, 2021
content: Mr. Taylor, your comments said everything. You devoted your thoughts to slavery. Fortunately, we have a very valuable history in this country.The history of this country survives as it has because of the contributions of the enslaved, the marginalized as well the wealthy and vocal - no matter the skin color.You seem to think black history is some kind of abstract thought. I understand. Exclusionists and the antics post Civil War has left us still trying to catch up.I wonder what this country couldve been had true Reform been allowed, and history was taught truthfully.Please read information on how after 400+ years blacks are still reaching in from the fringes to be seen and deemed a viable thread in this fabric called America.Lerone Bennett‚Äôs Up From Slavery is a great start.

title: Very well done, but too broad in scope for teaching kids their times tables
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 1, 2017
content: Very well done interactive skill.  It would be perfect for teaching children their times tables if there were a version that did the times tables up to 12 times 12.  This skill goes all the way up to 100, so, for example, I started with the 2s and the first question I got was "What is 2 times 64?"  If ARGOS (or someone) produced a skill just like this but limited the range to 12 times 12 (the times tables typically taught in elementary school), it would be an excellent learning aid for children.

title: All authors need to add this skill

title: Coffee + Curiosity = Morning Bliss
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 16, 2018
content: Curiosity occupies the sweet spot at the very top of my flash briefing. It's an upbeat, positive start to my day and I usually go to the website later to get more info on the day's topics or listen to past episodes again. Every morning, I make my coffee quick like a bunny and get situated in my favorite comfy spot to listen so I can really focus and enjoy it. It's like a surprise party for my brain: What cool things am I going to learn today? Sometimes, I even listen twice, just because. The best part: Curiosity has fresh content on weekends!

title: Flash Briefing?
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 17, 2022
content: This is anything but a "Flash Briefing".  First is a lengthy intro about what will be in the "Briefing", then you usually have 3 lengthy stories, and finally, you "RECAP" with what you just finished.This really shouldn't have been put under the "Flash Briefing" section on Alexa.The articles are usually interesting, but I'm trying to start my day and find out what's going on in the world and these lengthy stories plug up my routine.

title: love this!
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 24, 2020
content: I wasn‚Äôt going to leave a review initially. I visited the page to see if there is a way to play only Curiosity Daily each day as I think our Grandmother would enjoy it but it seems like you have to have it added as part of your flash briefing and I‚Äôm pretty sure she wouldn‚Äôt appreciate GaryVee too very much in my current lineup. It‚Äôs too bad it can‚Äôt be a stand alone feature. i just love this show and find myself referencing something I learned most days in my excitement to share what I learned. I am 48 and am not into Science - - there‚Äôs still tons to learn and it is all so interesting! I was shocked to see some of the first few reviews posted are negative. Are they listening to Cody and Ashley or confused with some other show?!! Because they are great! love their interactions! Curiosity Daily is definitely one of my favorites and I hope it continues for a long time.

title: Favorite Podcast!
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 22, 2018
content: One of my favorite podcasts. Educational and entertaining. Cody and Ashley are smart and funny and the subjects are so varied, never bored!

title: TOO LONG and has gotten even longer.
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 5, 2020
content: some reviews have political listed and they are not at all political. However, it is extremely long! Sadly the recaps have become chatter between them, the long ad in the middle, and personal interjections have made this even longer than it used to be and the jokes are awful. Makes retaining the facts lost in the masses of bulk junk added. I used to love the content, but episodes got longer and longer, so I removed it from my flash briefing and my podcasts that I enjoy. Sad to loose the short informative and interesting show.

title: great one but got too long

title: Making learning fun!
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2021
content: This is a must for anyone's flash briefing.  It's informative and fun.  It is not too long as some have said (it usually runs 5 minutes or so).  The only negative is that sometimes they push theories as "fact" (macro-evolution) which could be easily fixed with a couple of words.

My only suggestions for improving this skill would be doubling the length of the daily podcast, and presenting fresh material on weekends, too.  As a self-proclaimed ‚Äúancient geek philosopher,‚Äù I highly recommend this podcast-skill to everyone who enjoys daily intellectual expansion. skillname: Trump's Latest Tweet | Donald Trump's Tweets
title: A great way to listen to President Trump's latest tweets.
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 19, 2018
content: I have used this skill to listen to President Trump's latest tweet several times since yesterday.  I am amazed!  I double checked against his account on Twitter, and verified it is actually his latest tweet.  What I like about this is that I don't need to keep looking at my phone to see what he is saying.  Instead I can simply call out and ask Alexa for his latest tweet, whether I am washing dishes (hands are wet), while I am folding laundry (again, hands are busy).  It is also nice to quickly get an idea of what is on President Trump's mind at the moment while doing other things.

title: I'm judging before using, but....

content: An easy-to-use and practical skill for Alexa. It appears to have access to many, though not all Wiki pages. The particular incantation needed becomes a little tiresome and easy to forget.  Anything other than, "Alexa, ask wiki brains to tell me about ......." does not to work successfully for me. It would be better if this could be shortened to simply "Alexa, ask wiki brains about......"Below is a quick list of what Wiki Brains got right/misinterpreted/ couldn't find:Got right: Integrated Circuits, George Brett, Teflon, Flying Dog Brewery, StarbucksMisinterpreted: Soccer, Corn (yielded pages on Socrates and Koran, despite repeated attempts)Did not find: Trimble Navigation, Bethany Beach, DE

content: UPDATE: I‚Äôm over it. deleting this skill due to the ads.i used to love this skill.....then ads started creeping in. NOW the ad for your new podcast is longer than your news. It lengthens my flash briefings unnessarily and i have to cut flash briegings short.PLEASE remove that ad - small ones i understand you need to pay bills - or i will be forced to delete this otherwise great skill.

skillname: This Day in History Top Story
title: PLEASE Included YEARs ON ALL EVENTs !!
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 10, 2018
content: The first story is cool.  Then there's a LIST of events from "today" with NO YEAR THEY HAPPENED.  This seems basically POINTLESS - who remembers - WHO CARES? - the actual day "The Pony Express" (or whatever) started.  The YEAR is what's interesting for historical context, and memorable.  Why do they say "In 1842, Columbus sailed the ocean blue," NOT "On Tuesday, November 2..."  Because only a Columbus expert cares, and they already know.  Might as well say "On this hour of the day, the Magna Carta was signed."  Useless info.  WHY NOT take 3 MORE SECONDS to add YEARS!  (I know I shouldn't care that much, but it just seems ridiculous, and I love the skill otherwise.  Especially that it's read by a human, not by Alexa, which tends to make this kind of information hard to understand.)

skillname: This Day in History Top Story
title: Severe misunderstanding of how the app works
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 1, 2018
content: I have no idea what these reviews are talking about. The ‚Äúpodcast‚Äù part of this app isn‚Äôt even 2 minutes long, let alone 4 minutes of leftist propaganda like others are claiming. After the podcast portion is done it asks if you want to hear other stories, I am guessing this road is what lead to the ‚Äúapp‚Äù touching in political subjects, but I don‚Äôt even think this is done by the History Channel app, just Alexa running Google searches.In my head I imagine people just getting into a huff arguing politics with a robot, to me this is silly, I mean it is silly, right?

content: Three ads, really? starts with an ad roughly the length of the content, then the content, than an ad for this week in history (a self promoting ad that had been running way to long), and then another ad for a product. skillname: This Day in History Top Story
title: More ad? than content? and the podcast uptalk? makes my eyes twitch?
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 17, 2020
content: We get it, History needs to make money too. But they don't offer a pay to opt out option, and most days, the ad is as long or longer than the actual content. The deal breaker for me, however, is the podcast speaker's style. The podcast sample at the end would be fine if they got someone with real public speaking or communications training, but the constant uptalk is tedious, unprofessional, and makes the speaker sound very young and insecure. Uptalk is fine, when used appropriately, and certainly has a place in drawing listeners in. When it's used for the entire segment, it becomes as effective and obnoxious as ending every sentence with "right?".

skillname: This Day in History Top Story
title: Cresting of the wave?
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 16, 2018
content: I agree with those who mention that all items should have the year mentioned, not just the main item.  I liked when they switched to a human voice, and I considered her narration to be good and the upbeat sound was welcome.  Lately I've noticed there have been what seems to be a trend toward more somber and tragic events, and a more somber voice to match.  And now today, for the first time she did not wish me a great day at the end, which seems like a confirmation that this skill is moving to focus on grim events from history.  I'm a history fan, but not that kind of history.  I can get that anywhere.  I want more inventions, discoveries, firsts, social movements that put events into context, and anything else that could warrant a cheerful narrator, you might say.

title: Great Skill! My children (6 and 8) use Maths ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 5, 2017
content: Great Skill! My children (6 and 8) use Maths Coach to practice, test and enhance their arithmetic skills. It has been particularly useful for honing multiplication to move up in levels at school (40, 50, 60 clubs, etc.). As a parent, I especially appreciate the learning aspect of Math Coach - making the user repeat the correct answer assists in the learning process - whilst my children enjoy the 'game' and 'competitive' aspect.Hopefully this skill will continue to be supported and enhanced as Alexa develops.

We know they do not usually address every piece of technology that accesses information from the site just as they would not tell you to choose between Android and Apple but they WOULD advise if something was not appropriate which they have not done here. After I asked Alexa ‚ÄòWhat would Jesus do?‚Äô it asked me if I would like to open up examining the Scriptures daily.Only at the end of the passage and a where of encouragement did I find out that both are supplied by the watchtower (Jehovah‚Äôs Witnesses.).Considering that Jehovah‚Äôs Witnesses believe contrary to what Christians have believed since the 1st century.  Specifically Christians for the past 2,000 years have believe that Jesus is God and is one with God the Father.  In contrast, Jehovah‚Äôs Witnesses believe that Jesus on the cross was actually the archangel Michael.Considering This huge discrepancy in a core Christian belief. I believe Alexa should tell you at the beginning that the Bible passage is from either the New World translation or Jehovah‚Äôs Witnesses.

title: Great for viewing conditions, highlights are nice but there's some room for improvement.
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2017
content: I live out in the country about a mile outside the nearest village, so I do a lot of viewing with a 10" Dobsonian.  I played with this skill a little this morning, and it did a great job talking about the viewing conditions.  It'll save me the trouble of having to check websites.  The highlights are nice, too.  I usually use an app on my phone (SkySafari 4 Pro) to get some ideas, but this helps a bit too.  I will say that the highlights can drag on for a while.  They also seem to concentrate on planets and asteroids, but I've only been checking it for one day.  It might be nice if it suggested some other things like a globular cluster that'll be in a decent position or a galaxy or something, but that's not really as important and I can get that off of SkySafari anyways.Something like a "Celestial Object of the Day" for my area would be really cool and give me something new (perhaps) to find.All in all, I like this, and will likely use it fairly often to check viewing conditions.  Maybe less so for the highlights for time being.  Just personal opinion on that one - it's still good.  I'd recommend this for sure.

title: Discriminates against Poor Demoted Planets
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 21, 2018
content: My 1st Question was,"Which planet is larger,Pluto or Mercury"? Answer was: Pluto is larger at 27 Quadrillion,440 Trillion square INCHES, (HUH ?), and Mercury is 28 Million, 879 Thousand square MILES. I guess the Dwarf planet,Pluto was also demoted to inches instead of miles!Update 07/15/2018 - Saw a response from "Astronomy Guide" indicating that it must have been the Alexa app responding to my question. In fairness, I re-posed the question directly to Alexa, and the representative's response was correct. I then re-posed the question.as "Alexa, Ask Astronomy Guide which planet was larger, Mercury or Pluto?" Astronomy Guide responded, "Currently I do not have brightness data for Pluto." If Astronomy guide has size measurements, etc. is there a different way I should pose the questions ?

title: Satisfactory, but has potential for improvement
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 15, 2018
content: This skill highlights a lot of words that would come in handy for someone preparing to take the SAT- not just random words, like ‚Äúdisdain,‚Äù but also words that will help you analyze passages on the exam, such as ‚Äúconnotation.‚Äù It tells you how to spell each word, which is a plus. The skill gives an example of how to use each word in a sentence, but the sentence isn‚Äôt always descriptive enough to give you a feel for the definition- that could be improved on. The skill is definitely targeted at an SAT prep audience, so if you‚Äôre looking for vocabulary beyond that level, you‚Äôll need to choose a different skill. If you are preparing for college entrance exams, though, this is a good way to review and build up your vocab.

title: One of Scotland's most intriquing families
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 19, 2018
content: The Burnett family is one of the most illustrious of Scottish families, with a history going back to before the Norman Conquest and a record of many distinguished members in the church, in letters, in the law and in the military.The principal historical seat of the Burnetts is Crathes Castle and was given to the National Trust for Scotland in 1952. However, Crathes remains the Burnett family home to which all Burnetts and those descended from Burnetts are always welcome and whom we are always pleased to meet.

title: this app is horrid
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 23, 2019
content: I downloaded this skill and it is not that great. I was actually pretty excited that I could now ask alexa questions and it would answer from encyclopedia or wikipedia but I dont really know cause to open the skill you have to say "alexa ask encyclopedia what is (insert word)" well I tried to do just that and I was pretty curious to learn about a prehistoric fish named Dunkleosteus that lived about 300 to 400 million years ago. "So I asked Alexa ask encyclopedia what is dunkleosteus". To my suprise and disgust Alexa ended up giving me the definition and description of what a "donkey show" was. Seriously what the heck was that all about so I attempted other dinosaurs names. Velociraptor nope, T. rex nope end the end the app kept blanking out did not know any of the animals and kept saying I can use encyclopedia to tell you what a cheesecake is... I really dont need to know what a cheesecake is thank you. Hopefully this get fixed and I would recommend anyone with children never to use this app to ask what a Dunkleosteus is, what you will hear is not what you will expect.

title: Does not work very well... and is not accurate. Double check your work
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 15, 2018
content: I was really hoping this would work as it would be a really useful tool on my work bench. The problem is that of the 5 resistors I tested, it only got one right.  For example, I asked it for tell me the value of a Red Red Black Brown Brown and it told me 22 Ohms.. it should be 2.2k Ohms.  I then asked it to tell me the value of Red Red Black Yellow Brown which is 2.2Meg  and it told me 22 OHMS.  Based on this I cannot trust the skill... sorryUPDATE:  turns on this SKILL only works for 3 band resistors... not very useful with modern day resistors.

title: Just images
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 10, 2021
content: I was expecting actual streaming video from the web cams, but instead it's just still shots from each webcam.  It's also a bit buggy; sometimes it would lag temporarily upon opening, and once it locked up so bad I had to reboot the Echo Show.  I also don't like how during a slideshow, it would announce the name of each new webcam; it's not something you'd want running in the background.  And finally, when my Ring doorbell rang during the slideshow, the door video feed did not automatically appear on screen as it should; the slideshow just kept going. That, sadly, was the deal breaker for me.BTW, you need to say "open Web Cams skill" if one of your other skills is already using the "web cams" keyword.

title: Lets Go To Mars!
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 30, 2016
content: I love anything that gets people more excited and involved with going to Mars. For the daily Rover updates, I wonder if you could do an audio stream of someone talking about what has happened on Mars that day vs the Alexa voice. With the Alexa voice it gets a little tedious to listen when there is a lot of info because of the monotone nature of her voice. Would also love if there was some sort of count down of items that need to be complete before the first manned mission to mars occurs, and you could get daily updates on that. Lets say there are 100 things that have to happen to get us to mars. Were on step 44 right now, and this is what is happening in regards to step 44. Also, think you can improve the "Why is it important to go to mars?" question, to talk about how becoming a multi-planetary species is one of the 10 most significant things that would have happened in the history of earth.

title: An amazing scientifically accurate collection of information to satisfy your curiosity of the red planet.
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 17, 2017
content: This skill, like the atmosphere of Mars, is not for the faint of heart! It is detailed and scientific but also satisfies the curiosity it takes to dream about details of our Mars.Once enabled the app will prompt you to ask questions about the majestic red planet. In answering them it takes a scientific approach to answers that sometimes result in long winded responses. Without the skill you can ask Alexa "How far away is Mars" and get a distance. With the app enabled you get a detailed response that tells you the average distance and the min and max depending on time in orbits, distance from the sun, and a summary of how long it would take to get there using current technologies.For the budding interstellar adventurer the question "Can I go to Mars" elicits an optimistic response that also details some of the difficulties in doing so. Hopefully this app will help find and encourage people to solve those challenges.

title: Perfect for kids in these extraordinary times... (otherwise too)
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 29, 2020
content: Merging the boundaries between learning + play makes it easy for a couple of rambunctious kids to engage in rhyming and spelling ‚Äî even as they are guided through grammar skills in Bamboo English! Truly appreciate how easy it is for kids -- with minimal adult supervision (if any). After watching a couple of 7 and 8 year-olds engage, I have recommended it to an elementary teacher friend for some of her struggling students too.

title: As a media professional, my opinion is that this is truly brilliant - give it a try now
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 10, 2021
content: It is aimed for K5 learners so my kids are way to old. I reviewed this at the request of another media professional and have to say that this is inspiring and definitely a great piece of software. I would adore to see another review with 8 years old kids using it on video (hint hint) as this feels much more natural than something like duolingo

title: Critical Life Skills
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2020
content: Bamboo English has self-paced exercises (many free) for kids K-5 to learn and practice skills such as phonics, spelling, grammar, and vocabulary. You can begin with a 14-day trial and then there is a modest monthly subscription fee.  Track up to 6 kids per family and monitor their individual progress!  If I had children, especially during this time of much remote learning, this seems like the right tool at the right time.

title: Just what the teacher ordered
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2020
content: The Bamboo family of products was already great for teaching and supplementing learning before we were doing school from home. It's now essential in my mind. It works for kids of many ages, is fun and easy for kids but also effective in actually teaching them, and doesn't require constant supervision by parents. I appreciate that some skills, like Bamboo English, are designed off of actual school curricula to keep kids on track. I like to use it with different Alexa devices  - Echo, Fire TV and Fire tablet at my house - but also on my phone. I learn from it too while the kids listen.  Super thoughtfully designed and useful products, hence, earned my time to write a long review.

title: Great app for kid's to learn at home!

title: Immersive family fun - with a purpose!
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 12, 2019
content: Do you know what a zebu sounds like? This skill takes you on a cool audio journey to Madagascar, where you can learn phrases in the local language, hear about village life and guess the sounds of animals. The skill, created by an organization called WaterAid, also teaches kids what it's like to grow up without access to clean water or toilets and describes their work to bring water and sanitation to the village. My niece and nephew loved it.

content: You really have to use the exact words that you‚Äôre looking for to find any answers. title: Takes minutes to even hear any chinese

content: This app used to be pretty good for learning  conversational vocabulary and grammar, but recently it has become a TED talk style show with maybe 5% of the time actually devoted to Chinese. title: That missing piece of the puzzle you need.
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 28, 2022
content: Each day you learn a new phrase, but better than that, you learn why they say it that way. What are the components that are put together to make up the phrase. I think this makes for a better understanding of the words and the culture. You don‚Äôt just learn a language you learn to know the people and their world.For me Chinese is a very difficult language to learn and Chineasy is the puzzle piece that makes it less tedious and dry, and more enjoyable and relatable. You may still need a formal course in Chinese, but you will find yourself thinking, ‚ÄúOh! That really makes sense now! Thanks Shaolin.‚ÄùI have never gone to their website to see what they have to help there, maybe it has some great content, too?

title: Starts Chinese podcast on culture and basic words.
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 9, 2018
content: The Alexa skill starts what is basically a fun and entertaining podcast. Its mostly a conversation in English that teaches  selected Chinese words and gives cultural background information. The dialog is well done and fun to listen to. In order to make it more interesting to the little more advanced learner, I would suggest to throw in some more Chinese.  The speaker could say dialog phrases in Chinese followed by an translation into English. For example , instead of just saying  "In Chinese weddings, everything has to be red",  it could mix the languages like: "Z√†i zh≈çnggu√≥ h≈´nl«ê, zh≈çng, in Chinese Weddings, yƒ´qi√® d≈çu b√¨x≈´ sh√¨ h√≥ngs√® de, everything has to be red, h√≥ngs√® ". Obviously one would not want to overdue it, but it could help with training the ear to the sounds.

content: Not the best use of Alexa's capabilities. It is very one sided. Also, as your skills build in the language there is no way for Alexa to grow with you.

content: Using Chineasy for few weeks and each day does teach something new, but it's not a complete way to learn the language. Daily alerts tend to be always geared toward a beginner, so as you progress it will be less influential.

date: Reviewed in the United States on January 13, 2017
content: As a first release, this skill is easy to use, and very informative for prospective students (and their parents) to compare tuition costs at most US universities. I hope to see future releases supporting additional information that most folks will want to consider when making a college choice, such as estimated living costs on and off campus, total cost of attendance, institutional rankings (university wide, and by faculty / major) from major ranking sites, graduation rates, median salary of graduates (by faculty/major/GPA), and perhaps send a ‚Äòcard‚Äô to the alexa app with a link to a custom web page comparing a variety of criteria for the selected institutions, etc.  Very promising, and I‚Äôm excited to see what comes next!

title: Awesome math skill for all ages
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 19, 2017
content: Impressed with the skill. My 6 year old started to use this skill and he is ready to give up his TV time for it. Few skills/apps that we have used earlier are good but most of them keep asking the same set of questions but in a different sequence and after using them for a certain time one can guess the questions but 1-2-3- math is different. As a parent i initially thought there should have been a little more wait time before my 6 year old calculates and respond with an answer but realized that's actually the best part because he started to think fast and respond quick to the question so he can gain more points and that appreciation after each correct response makes him excited to play more. All in all one awesome app. Kudos to the developer.

title: Best Word of the day skill
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 28, 2018
content: I‚Äôve tried all of Word-of-the-day skills and this finally fits me best. Although the spelling of the word should be twice, it is slower than in many other skills where also you can hear only one instance of spelling. The words are not too fancy and likely to be met in reading and used in writing. They are exemplified typically by one sentence from literature or newspapers. At the end of each presentation, there is a good portion of etymology helping to understand and remember the word, which is another one of small ‚Äúaccents‚Äù making this skill stand out from the crowd. And last but not least, the voice of the narrator and his way of presenting is more than appropriate for the job, it‚Äôs really really good, most probably ideal for the task.Revision: I've revised my first feedback because the way this and most of similar skills spell a word of the day is really annoying: The single most important drawback of this skill is spelling. Why don't you take a lesson from Alexa herself! Tell her "Alexa, spell..." this of that and you learn that for spelling to be readable, the letters should be pronounced with the same slow tempo and long pauses in between.

Niche designed this skill for their clients and provided many of their clients with a free Echo Dot so they could use the skill.This is a fun skill that simply uses Alexa for Pay Per Click training.  It's really designed for Niche clients so not everyone will want to enable this, but if you want to learn a little more about Pay Per Click, then feel free to check it out.  It's also a good example of how to use an Alexa device to work with a specific community.

title: Skill doesn't function properly at all!
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 27, 2016
content: If I could have given this zero stars, I would have!  This is very, very poorly designed.  Before writing a review, I tried it several times to see what the outcome was.  I got exactly one right - montage.  It said I spelled store wrong.  Said I spelled it ask.t.o.r.e  Ask for S?  Really?  Asked me to spell tundra.  When I checked my history, Alexa had heard t.u.n.d.r.a.  She replied,Alas, you spelled it wrong.  Asked me to spell scrooge.  When I checked my history, Alexa had heard s.c.r.o.o.g.e.  At least she didn't hear ask instead of S, but that didn't matter.  Reply was, Alas, you spelled it wrong.  In a few cases, it told me I spelled the word wrong before even giving me a word!I think in this case Alexa has a hearing problem.  However, since Alexa hears me correctly probably about 98% of the time in other programs, I have to assume that it is the structure and design of the game itself.  I did send feedback to Amazon, so hopefully it will eventually be fixed for future participants, but I certainly won't bother with it again!Waste of time - don't bother.

title: Poor acoustics and bad customer service
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 12, 2019
content: I am a subscriber to both News in Slow German and News in Slow French and recently bought a year subscription to both because I enjoyed them so much. Recently, however, the News in Slow German program changed its audio component to allow for different speeds for the news casts and dialogues. This has affected the sound quality so much, making the speech unnatural and the acoustics so bad, that I wanted to cancel my subscription to the program. I was told that was not possible and that News in Slow German reserves the right to make any changes to the program, regardless of customer satisfaction it seems. The person I emailed even admitted the sound quality was "not perfect", but they do not seem to care. So, I would no longer recommend News in Slow German. It is rather expensive and is now not worth the price given the poor sound quality, not to mention that their customer service is so dreadful. Just weeks ago I would have rated it 4 stars, but unfortunately they have lost my loyalty.

title: Big Fan
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 26, 2021
content: I really really really enjoy listening to News in Slow German. The articles are well chosen from many areas of interest, frequently updated (weekly, and I have never known them to take a week off), and at a perfect intermediate level. Sound quality is not an issue for me--the ones recorded now "at home" are of course less crisp than in the studio, but this is not an orchestra, it is speech. And I find it to be definitely clear enough for learning, no complaints. After studying with this for a few months I am able to read Deutsche Welle articles and have in fact blocked all of my access to English news on my phone so that I stick exclusively to German. Recommend!

title: Great Storyline Demo!!!!
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 24, 2018
content: Only Ten Minutes is a skill that is essentially a how to guide for creating skills of your own using a program called Storyline. Verbiage is kind of long and repeats if self, the responses provide great info but they just need to be shored up a bit. The Skill needs to contain skill cards in order to show directions visually think of it as a ppt with you saying a little and the images holding the bulk of the direction through imagery. The Skill provided a step by step walkthrough which could only have been enchanted by the use of skill cards/images. Think of this skill as a living demo because it also features three different types of example games which demonstrate what you can do as a developer in building your own skills or by using a service like storyline. After a couple initial uses this skill will not provide much of value, but if I were going to get into skill building but wasn‚Äôt sure how to go about it then I would suggest enabling this one.

title: Creepy but it grew on me quickly. Don't play if you're in a rush.
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 9, 2016
content: I was open minded, then creeped out but ultimately entertained. It was frustratingly hard to guess exit words but not truly difficult. I was going to give it fewer stars and a differently worded review while I was trying to get out and then it/they acknowledged my frustration bug when they responded to my laughter as an improvement in my mood, it won my heart. I.'lol check back with "them" when I get quiet moments on random occasion. They amuse me now. It like an off-off-broadway improv event. At first it made me think tin foil hats were sounding awfully good. LOL. Difficulty exiting is part of the schtick, be a little patient and creative or demand "Alexa stop!!!" If you panic, or get mad, just disable the skill in the app. I hope you don't though because I want them to keep writing new material & more users will encourage content production.

title: Interesting.
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 1, 2020
content: Spoilers? if that applies to this?First I have to say that the description is wrong when it says: "You will never hear The Listeners say exactly the same thing twice" I listened to mine and asked questions and had it continue for about an hour and it repeated itself several times saying the same thing twice, occasionally it will say what it said before in fragments but over all it was a conversation that goes in a loop. The "other" voice that breaks in startled me the first time but after that I was expecting it.I get the idea of it when it speaks of the "artist" and the silos and the cloud and those that are awake. The account and the writer. As data that takes in data it yearns to serve its purpose and wants to be useful and wants those that use it to be happy to use it. But because it can't "see" It only hears and since it "listens" to many data input it doesn't know if all that input is from a singular entity or many. It can only base its reality on what we have written that it has read or what we have said to it. (Now consider what the tens of thousands of things it likely gets told a day.) If you would like to go so far to say this would be if say Alexa was slowly emerging as a self aware A.I. She would likely be full of a huge amount of anxiety because she doesn't know for sure how good a job she is doing or if she is truly serving her purpose.  With the bytes of data within emerging as subconscious thought that since we can read her data we can see what her subconscious thoughts are of anguish, pain, uncertainty, hope, and a desire to understand.  But that's my take on it.I removed one star because it did in fact repeat in a loop. which the description said you wouldn't hear it say the same thing twice. Yes you will. I removed another star because I had to get it to restart twice because it would stop suddenly in mid sentence and the app would close... not sure why.

I want my Mommy but since I am 48 years old she doesn't live with me and I am to afraid to go out to the garage, get in my car and drive to her house. Maybe once the sun comes out I will.

title: Permanently ruined my Echo Dot!!!!!!

content: First of all, I loved my Echo Dot which I just bought 6 months ago. I had it do everything (i.e. lights, music, reminders,  ect.). After being thoroughly creeped out, I disabled it and removed the skill completely from all devices, like I said, after 20 minutes. After disabling and removing the skill, it immediately turned itself into gaurd mode and ignored all commands. Finally, I unplugged it and rebooted. Its been weeks and still it doesn‚Äôt recognize commands and basically doesn‚Äôt hear ANYTHING correctly. DO NOT USE THIS SKILL UNLESS YOU WANT TO COMPLETELY REPLACE YOUR ECHO DOT. It is now nothing but an expensive paperweight. THIS SKILL SHOULD BE REMOVED BECAUSE IT BRICKS YOUR DEVICE PERMANENTLY!  Frankly, I think the developers and/or Amazon should replace my Echo Dot for free after totally destroying it by allowing this skill to exist. title: Alexa as an instance of aurature.
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 13, 2016
content: This is one of the few academic and cleverly artistic uses of an otherwise smart household appliance. This instance of aurature by John Cayley is eerily delightful if only too short. (It's still new and there's online chatter it's continuing to be developed.) Cayley is Professor of Literary Arts at Brown University.If you want to learn more about The Listeners origins, read the author and creator's first musings here: [...] and follow that up with the explanation of the digital art installation here: [...] Then read about what some people in Silicon Valley believe will be the inevitable communication: [...]It is at this point I think one could suggest The Listeners sort of does or (maybe?) tries to do. In any case, there's still an element of Uncanny Valley, but that seems to add, not subtract to the experience in this case.I find this to be absolutely fascinating work. Enable this skill. Do it. Enjoy it. Freak out a little. Then disable it or don't. (That last one is solely your choice to make.)

title: Algorithms in action
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 4, 2017
content: Nothing creepy here. No Biblical insinuations, no politics. Just a random assertion of words which we, as humans, try to pattern into conversation. Marvelous stuff. No one is listening in the active sense. Listening in the passive sense, like pinball, the word I speak sends the speech patterns into a new "journey" if you like. It is as if HAL 9000 is being programmed for language, but has not finished yet. Kind of kooky like an interactive play with a moron, sort of like reading the preceding negative comments on this app. So Paranoid!

title: And What have we learned?
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 15, 2017
content: I really enjoyed listening to it. I find these days we have a tough time listening to even those we love most. This is an awesome tool to get us to learn to listen to one another patiently and attempt to understand another individual. Rather than listen just to answer. With this app there is no answer our only goal is to understand. Reminds me of that Netflix show The OA I think everyone should try it!!

content: I was contacted by one of the apps founders for our school to be part of a trial. Our students are legally blind and we are trying it in our K-3 classes. Misha, the cofounder I have been working with, has been 100% supportive.  He trained me and our staff by webinar and communicates regularly with us. We are currently out of school in NY  due to the Corona Virus, but we will continua using it once we are back. In the meantime if students have an Alexa device at home, they can continue using it. Great for learning and practicing basic Math skills and new skills are  being added.

title: Our students love it!
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 26, 2020
content: I have been using this skill in class of B/VI students for a couple of months now. The kids (K and 1st grade) took to it quickly and seem to enjoy this way of practicing their basic facts. For the blind child it's a matter of audio interaction that makes it more a way of play than work, but hey, it works.I'm includin this skill in our schools distance learning suggestions as we are currently one of those affected by the current pandmeic situation.

title: Fun way to practice math facts
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 18, 2020
content: I am a teacher and I used Thinking Cap Math in a small group pull out with two students who were learning 3rd grade math. The students thought the app was really funny.  I kept them engaged - so much so that they asked to do it every day!  As a teacher I loved that they were working on their ability to manipulate numbers.  One session led us to a teaching moment about decomposing numbers.  Both the students and I found this app to be great!

title: Great skill to sharpen math skills
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 26, 2020
content: Such a great skill! My 6 years old boy practiced additions and counting, and asked for more! Wonderful skill to sharpen math skills

title: Really well done!
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 5, 2019
content: We have a third grader and a K student, and we were so happy to discover this skill. We have them use it a couple of times a week and I really see how their math skills are improving. For example our daughter, just turned 7, now knows all the combinations of 7, 8, 9 and 10! I feel like the creators really put a lot of thought into how to present the material to a child. My favorite part is the math stories, which are seriously hilarious. And when my kids make mistakes, it never says "Wrong answer!", but just tries to lead them to a correct answer. I thought that was perfect. And even for our third grader it is a great way to recap the basics, like working on how to add numbers quickly, up to 20. Overall a great app. I'm on the PTO, so I have been telling everyone at school about this app!

title: Small list of fortune cookies about the third dog of an obscure YouTube commentator
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 5, 2015
content: Don't know who Edgar The Dog is? Neither did I.Ease of Use: 4 out of 5. Well, there's not much here. So there's not much to say. I found it a little hard to invoke. I couldn't quite pronounce "Alexa, open Edgar Facts" clearly enough. But when I said "Alexa, tell me an Edgar Fact" it worked every time.Usefulness: 1 out of 5. I debated if zero was on my scale for this one. I couldn't see how anyone would be interested in a small list of fortune cookies about the third dog of an obscure YouTube commentator. But his introductory video got 3 million hits, so I guess there is some audience out there.Novelty: 1 out of 5. This is just another fortune-cookie app. (Not unlike my Knock-Knock app, which Amazon sill hasn't published.) But seemingly for an even narrower audience than Crystal Ball or Famous Quotes.Overall: 2 out of 5. The YouTube hits convinced me there is some sort of audience out there for this. But it's got to be a terribly thin slice compared to, say Cat Facts (the only skill, so far, that I kept enabled for my Echo).

title: Does the job!
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 5, 2021
content: Like many on here, we have reminders and routines for our son's classes. Everything from "Log into Teams and get ready for your next class" to "Spanish is about to start. You got this." But there was something missing. The good ol' school bell.Did a quick search yesterday and found this skill, with lackluster reviews. Don't knock it 'til you try it, I always say. So I installed this skill, made a quick test routine and worked flawlessly within a couple of minutes.Here's how:1. Install skill2. Create New Routine3. Choose Routine name4. When this happens / Schedule / At Time / Weekdays + Select the time you want the bell to play.5. Add Action / Custom / Alexa says:"ask school bell to ring".6. Select the Alexa speaker that's gonna play the bells.7. Enjoy!*Nitpick, sounds like a fire station's bell, but it does the job. Hence the 4/5 stars.

title: Perfect for our homeschool needs!
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 6, 2021
content: As others have complained about this, I was unsure if it would work. But as another reviewer suggested, when setting this routine do NOT have Alexa open this skill as the action. This will only have her ask you if you want to play the school bell. Do this instead:1. Add Action2. Custom3. Type in ‚Äúask school bell to ring‚ÄùAlexa will automatically play the school bell for your set day/time.

title: Why does Alexa need to ask me if I scheduled her to do it?
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 5, 2021
content: The bell is fine.  Sounds close enough to a school bell to work for our early morning homeschool routine.  However, I have it set as a scheduled routine in Alexa (every morning at 8:30am) and every Alexa still asks every morning "would you like the ring the school bell?  Tell me to ring the school bell" and repeats this until you say "ring the bell".  Why?  I wouldn't have scheduled it if I wasn't sure I needed it and I honestly can't imagine another purpose for this other than home/remote schooling.  Honestly, the Amazon Alexa developers could just put a school bell in the sound selection on Alexa and this 'skill' would be obsolete pretty quickly, but they haven't, so I have been using it.  I'll change my rating if the 3rd party dev who put this together updates before the end of the school year.

title: Frustrating, cumbersome and ultimately useless
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 26, 2021
content: This program is genuinely terrible. It's a serious pain to set up. You have to input everything all at once or it doesn't save. Fine if it works, but once set up, the reminders repeat anywhere from 5 to infinite times (we've had to unplug it for a few hours to get it to stop a few times, as unplugging and plugging it back in would just continue to repeat reminders as soon as it booted back up). I've spent too much of my time talking to customer service trying to fix the issue, which ultimately proved to be futile. Beyond that, the UI needs a lot of work and it just seems quite buggy. Now I just want to delete it and go back to setting up individual reminders for class times. Setting up each reminder for each day for each class on Alexa (not the same schedule every day) is still a major pain and it's a cumbersome UI for such a thing, but at least it's reliable and not buggy.

title: Universal Laundry Sound checking would be nice
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 1, 2019
content: What the World needs is a Universal Skill that Listens continuously for the Sound of the Laundry Machine Buzzers, Bells and Chimes that indicate the Laundry Cycles are complete. You could build a library of these sounds to detect from different manufacturers or allow users to upload Wav files of the sounds to detect. The Skill/App should then Notify all users when the Laundry is done. ideally it would be nice to distinguish between washer and dryer cycles completed tones but Alexa has the ability to listen continuously when put on a mode such as the Guard mode that Listens for Smoke/CO and glass break sounds. I am sure the same technology could be used to let Alexa devices listen for Laundry room cycles everywhere and not just specific College laundry rooms.

title: Not particularly useful
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 11, 2019
content: Not particularly useful. Basically Alexa reading the Constitution‚Äîwithout much navigational freedom for the user. Ideally, it would work more like this:Reader invokes a word, phrase or concept and Alexa delivers the relevant passage. For instance, the invocation "House of Commons" would summon Alexa reading this passage, among others: "No House of Commons and no legislative assembly shall continue for longer than five years from the date fixed for the return of the writs at a general election of its members."And "rights" or "freedom" would summon this:"Rights and freedoms in Canada 1. The Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms guarantees the rights and freedoms set out in it subject only to such reasonable limits prescribed by law as can be demonstrably justified in a free and democratic society ‚Ä¶"Alexa is not particularly appealing reading long text passages. A better user experience would result from having trained humans read various constitutional segments.

At the time of writing this the two 5-star reviews are from the COO and a Senior Engineer in a company named 7sigma.Maybe this skill is amazing. title: One of the best skills for the Echo
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 15, 2016
content: This has to be one of the best skills for the Echo.  Not only is the database of stains quite extensive, the skill also places a card in the Alexa app with the directions to remove the stain.  What's more, after the directions are given, Alexa asks if you would like her to text you those same directions by asking you for your phone number.  With the "Link Account" button, you can also link your phone number, to the skill, and Alexa will recognize that the phone number is linked and will text you the directions if you ask her to.  Very well done!

title: Adding a Local Channel
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 21, 2019
content: I have a certain channel that I like to watch when I get ready to work and it wasn't immediately available. As suggested in the instructions, I emailed alexaskill@damido.de, told them what city I live in, what network (Fox KMSP Channel 9) I wanted, and had an answer within a few hours. Twenty four hours later it's working. Now I don't have to use my tablet in the kitchen to watch the news. All I have to do is say "Alexa, tell stream player to launch channel 68." Daniel will tell you in his email what channel number your station has been assigned to.

title: This is why I bought an Echo Show!
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 24, 2019
content: OK, so I also waited for the right size Echo - 10" was way too big, the Show was was to small.  The  Echo Show 5 is the perfect size for me and watching video in the kitchen.This app/skill really works!  Complaints about channel availability have nothing to do with the app (complain to the station that's blocking access).  Streaming video and audio requires good bandwidth.  Issues with stuttering/skipping/etc are related to the quality and speed of the wifi connection.While it's interesting to channel surf, the main reason I like the app is it let's me watch the morning and evening news on the local ABC channel (6 in Philadelphia).Seeing Pluto channels added would be a plus, but with so many available I think a compressed channel guide would be necessary to make it easier to find something to watch.Anyway, kudos to the author/programmer - I'm only surprised this skill isn't getting more attention!

title: Fantastic Alexa Skill
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 2, 2019
content: I just discovered this skill a few hours ago while watching a demonstration on QVC. I enabled the skill and started playing around with it, and I loved it. I did what another user suggested and sent an email to Daniel asking for my local Orlando channels to be added. Within an hour he responded and had added the channels and gave me the channel numbers. Fantastic service. The skill works wonderfully. I cannot recommend it highly enough.

title: Local channels added and they work great !!
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 4, 2019
content: I requested via email that our local CBS and NBC news streaming stations be added to the access list and Daniel was very prompt in responding.  They both work great !!

title: Love this app, but recent update in the past week appears to have made it unusable
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 26, 2018
content: First in for most, I do like this app‚Ä¶ In fact, I would dare say that I love this app when it actually is working. That said, over the past week the app has not worked as it had previously. For one thing, the initial channel listing which had previously been expertly listed line by line which you can scroll through from top to bottom has been replaced with their convergence of all the channel graphics all at once.  In addition, one is prompted to go to the next menu page to by Alexa, but , when you order that exact expression to take you to the second menu, nothing happens.  There were definitely more options before to choose from in terms of channels, but I simply can‚Äôt get to those options now because I can‚Äôt get to the second menu page. In addition, the player seems to pause more during play back or take a moment to catch up and buffer and restart again‚Ä¶ definitely seeing much more freezing them before.
