title: best free tv and only skill
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 31, 2020
content: I downloaded this after I discovered I could stream cbsnews for free on my echo show 5. This is really cool! There are lots of locals that only work when the news is on during local times, but there are many that are free all the time like pbs kids, weather nation, national news channels, buzzr tv, etc. Its endless. Its like antenna tv but with out the hit or miss of digital over air. I‚Äôm super happy. There are some glitches and sometimes it freezes if the channel is not available or not working. You have to go home and restart but once it works, it streams nicely. I will mention some channels like Retrotv, Earth Cam, or NHK are not working at this time.  However, it is a great kitchen companion while cooking. I definitely recommend this skills even for the heck of it. It works!

title: Primitive
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2019
content: The concept of ear training on Alexa is great.  This system is a simple execution of the concept. It might teach you to recognize intervals better, but you will have to be patient with the system's quirks.  If you say an interval is a "perfect fifth" instead of "fifth" then it marks you wrong. If you say an interval is a "third" then you get that wrong because you didn't say MAJOR third, even though minor thirds are not tested at that level. Then, if you get more than 10% wrong questions on a level, you have to wade through the entire level again to work up to a higher level where you're challenged -- there is no "honor system" allowing more experienced students to jump up to higher levels if you dare to try that.  Another quirk: if the system can't hear your response, or you give your response immediately after hearing the tones but before the system has decided it's ready to listen to you, then you have to wait through a long explanation of lots of rules before you get another chance to give the answer.  These quirks are frustrating and made me feel like my time was being wasted.

title: Pretty much what it says. You can't get simpler than this
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 5, 2015
content: Ease of Use: 4 out of 5. There isn't much to using this skill, because there isn't much to this skill. A few of the readings came out a bit weird, due to Alexa's Text To Speech, and those could have been edited or removed. Also, it doesn't put up any companion app cards, so I couldn't check out the text of it when it went wrong, or when I really liked it and wanted to copy it.Usefulness: 3 out of 5. This fits the scenario of "I'm sitting on my couch, drinking a beer, and I...". It's a "timewaster app", but, then again, so are the mobile apps I use the most. I can't fault it for that.Novelty: 1 out of 5. I'm pretty sure the developer threw this together in an hour or so. Although I admire the brilliance of  getting Amazon to select an app with so little work (unlike mine which is one of the ones that has been waiting months) there really isn't much there. The forthcoming Angry Bard and Focus Word skills from LME are substantially the same (the other two certified, but unpublished for months skills I am aware of).Overall: 3 out of 5. It's got general appeal. I think it could use a little clean up. Plenty of scope for companion skills like "Movie Quotes", "<insert religion> Quotes", "Funny Quotes", etc. Or, making the skill a little more complex and giving you the option of selecting a category within the skill.

title: Actually Works
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 15, 2019
content: Set up is a bit slow, but it actually works so I'm okay with that. We've tried others and this is the first one that actually works the way we need it too. There are some normal issues with kiddo needing to speak up, but that is not a skills issues, so much as an echo dot that we deal with anytime kiddo is interacting wth an echo dot or echo show. I was just thrilled to find a spelling skills that lets us use our own words and spelling, and that lets the kid actually spell the words and says if it's correct or not (rather than just being able to use it for review, or always saying it's wrong). I'm a grad student and helping kiddo practice spelling eats into my own coursework time significantly. Kiddo can use this at home while I'm doing my coursework, and we just review in the car.

title: I used to love the the device
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 7, 2021
content: Alexa used to respond correctly to what is my notice, now she responds with there are no timers set, until I change my wording to what is my notification, not sure what happened, but it is going backward in understanding, not forward.  Also twice now she give me a national weather advisory and when asked for the forecast she says partly sunny.  I never knew there was a national weather advisory for partly sunny weather.  When asked about the advisory and what it is for, she cannot answer. Like some of the other reviewers, I have to go to google to get most of my information.  I love the music play lists and it is what I use most often.  However, today I asked her to play Christmas music and she couldn't find any.  I sincerely hope she stops going backward and that the features we have been using are not lost.

title: Not all that!  Expensive option for a machine not quite ready to handle basic questions
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 26, 2019
content: Excellent concept and one day, maybe this gadget will do a much better job at the difficult skills that it purports to handle, but, right now: Ehhhh, not all that.  The Echo I purchased less than a month ago is going back for a full refund.  I can do without this because my biggest thing is that I like fundamentally easy access to reliable information.  I cannot even get to evaluate whether the information that I have received in reponse to my queries, but I try to keep the request brief or succinct so that there is no window of misinterpretation to my questions for example: Alexa, at what temperatures to average electric drying machines operate?  Her response: Hum, I don't know that. Or, Alexa, tell me a recipe for backed chicken breasts.  Her response: Hum, I don't know that or Hum, for Parmesan encrusted chicken (this is her response over 5 times of asking the preceeding question too.  It may be adequate for some, but I think the recognition software used or the methodology employed with this device makes it a pricey option for a bunch of: "Hum, I don't know that" responses to short and basic questions.  I'm done.  I would give it - 1 if it were allowed.

title: I LOVED (past tense) Alexa
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 18, 2021
content: I suspect that we are in the top 1 or 2 percent of Alexa users.  While eating dinner every night, we play question of the day ( we have a total of 3559 points) and then Jeopardy.  We are in the top 100% of players every week; not because we are smarter but because we are more diligent.  It was a tradition.  Over the past two weeks, when we give answers, all we get is  "Please answer in the form of a question, like... "  no matter how loud or precise we speak.  It is so bad that we routinely cuss at the inanimate object.  I was hoping that we would be able to keep the tradition going, but I guess we will switch to the nightly news if all we can do is curse an inanimate object.

title: strange beeping noises
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 27, 2019
content: Alexa was off, then suddenly started making beeping sounds.  the light was flashing blue with cyan.  I asked Alexa to play Christmas music. it said.."here's a station you might like from Amazon", but didn't play anything, it just kept beeping. I finally told it  "Alexa, off" and it turned off. THEN it started to play Christmas music, and there was NO light at all on top. very strange behavior.  1/2 hour later, still playing Christmas music, still no color on the rim.  Alexa usually works flawlessly and I've enjoyed it immensely!

title: Alexa really doesn't know much
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 11, 2020
content: I am really disappointed in Alexa. I thought she would be comparable to Siri. She doesn't know the basic information. Sometimes I have a really hard time just to get her to tell me what network the packer game is on. So many questions I ask her are "hmmmm I don't know that?" Maybe I expected too much. I thought I could ask her the things that google answers but she doesn't know. Even a lot of definitions. I don't need a companion or someone to play games with or tell jokes to. They seem to be adding those kind of options. COME ON!!!! I don't want her to be my friend, just info.  If I need information I usually end up going to google because she doesn't know. She is good for the weather and music and my grands like to play with her but overall I am disappointed. Hoping for improvements down the road

title: Wrong weather forecasts

title: When News is no longer actual news
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 10, 2019
content: HI,I have now some 7 Alexa devices and another 1 coming at the end of this month. Until very recently I was extremely happy with the system, I had tried others but found this was the one for me. Most mornings I ask for " News " after I've had a shower but lately the news has been at least 12 hours old......not really news it it !Today the news was about a US visitor who " departed today ".......today is Monday, he left on Thursday so how can it be news.Can this be sorted out......or am I putting Alexa on the Ebay and move to " Hey........"

title: Yes, you need to switch your Alexa to German, but ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 30, 2020
content: TLDR; If you can get past the 5 second heartache of having to switch your Alexa to German, do your preaching session, then switch it back to your native language when you are finished, it can be a very helpful tool.Although you need to switch your Alexa to German temporarily, I have not found this to be a problem personally.  I only do the preaching on my Alexa app on my smartphone, so when I am setting aside time to work on preaching, it takes all of 5 seconds to switch my Alexa to German, not a big deal to me.Now, about the actual skill, I have found it can be more helpful than using Speechnotes or Google translate mainly because it asks me everything in a seemingly random order and does not give me a lot of time to 'process', which forces me to recall the right answer naturally like you would when speaking to a real person.  I did not think I would like this at first, but after a little bit of practice, it actually works really well!

title: Fast progress in speaking German
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 29, 2018
content: Preaching is one of the quickest ways my speaking has progressed in German. For me it takes a lot of practice to establish the mental patterns for the articles and adjectives to roll out smoothly.  Before this course I had been faking it, swallowing my articles and adjectives in the hopes that no one would notice. When things were moving fast I had no idea what was correct. This gives me confidence when speaking.Another area that has really helped me is in sentence structure. Past perfect and with complex sentences with clauses and "pushers": words that send all the verbs to the end of sentences. This is a real Godsend since it established patterns that I now use without thinking any more.There are times when Alexa doesn't like what I have said and I know I said it right. At first I found this frustrating but, later took it to mean that i have to really pay attention to how I am saying things. I'm learning to pay more attention to my pronunciation and to really speaking the words out with clarity. We still sometimes have stubborn arguments but they are fun now. In general I notice that when I speak with people in German here in Switzerland they understand me better than before. I find this very satisfying.

It covers hearing and repeating back very basic vocabulary and common phrases. Unfortunately I found the voice recognition to be poor in the sense it kept asking for me to repeat what I said. That doesn‚Äôt happen to me with regular Alexa command or other skills. It ended up frustrating to use because of this. If they improved the voice recognition and could come up with a creative way to integrate with my regular Rosetta Stone training, this could easily be a ‚Äúkiller app‚Äù usage for Alexa and Amazon‚Äôs Echo devices. For now, however, it‚Äôs capabilities are very underwhelming, but the potential is there if Rosetta Stone is willing to invest in it.

title: Supported utterances
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 2, 2017
content: * Alexa, ask How Far is <Destination>* Alexa, ask How Far is <Destination> from <Origin>* <Destination>* <Destination> from <Origin>When <Origin> is not specified - device postal code code is used, if permitted. Otherwise, "Seattle, WA" is used.Both <Destination> and <Origin> can be any location on a map - a city, a postal code, a state, or a name like "Yellowstone Park". If Alexa doesn't get it right - adding state name (Portland, Oregon) usually helps.The skill isn't specific to US, any country is supported. But, obviously, attempting to drive from Seattle to Rio won't quite work (but feel to try it!).

title: EDITED: Responsive customer service
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 4, 2019
content: EDITED: I initially had an issue when trying to enable the app to work with Alexa. Customer service addressed the issue with Amazon and followed up to make sure I was able to connect.What I love:As someone who's studied a lot of languages, seriously for school and international work, and eve casually for travel, Pimsleur's audio-based approach is the most effective approach to improving speaking/listening skills. I love that the audio continues when the app is closed, just like music or a podcast. But unlike before the app when I had to listen to the lessons through music or my audible app, the app gives a devoted platform for language learning that makes it easier to keep track of your progress, even when you decide to go back and repeat previous lessons. The added visual component of the mobile app and the review exercises really improve the experience and reinforce the lessons.What could be improved:The flash card function would be better if it showed a list of the words you are reviewing before hand. It's helpful to know which words you are already very familiar with and which ones you know you need help with. You sometimes end up wasting your time with words you already know very well. It would help to be able to tag the words/phrases that need special attention and have a "smart" deck of those troublesome items. I also wish, that there was a scrollable script to follow along with the audio. It would be helpful when rewinding or fast forwarding, or when you're trying to a particular lesson or part of a lesson. Also, there are times when you're listening and still have trouble making out a given word.Pimsleur should be a part of your language learning regimen, along with a good set of flash cards for expanding/reinforcing vocabulary, and a small grammar book for when you're feeling ready for a more advanced understanding of the structure of the language.

title: Great for language learning but this app is buggy
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 15, 2021
content: Learning languages is my favorite thing in the world, and Pimsleur is truly an excellent program. I love it so much that I signed up for access to all their languages and was excited to link to my Echo so I could easily do my lessons. Unfortunately, Alexa will only play the last language I was exploring and I can't change which language I'm working on. I even disconnected the app and reconnected, but she's stuck. The process of opening the app is also tedious, and it's so difficult to close the Pimsleur app on Alexa as well. She doesn't like to quit out of Pimsleur. An amazing resource that's being held hostage by Alexa.

I‚Äôd like to skip the beginning and go directly to where I left off ü§¨.but i like the simplicity of being able to hear sentences in German and i like that it connects to my Amazon alexa device.  if they added those features i mentioned it would be perfect.

title: Buggy and Confusing
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 8, 2018
content: I think Pimsleur is great, having used it for Spanish, Hebrew, German, Japanese, and now Mandarin. There is no better way, I think, to learn a language. But this Alexa app... Whew. Did they throw it together in a half hour? It is barely useable, and only that much because I‚Äôve managed to guess the correct prompts to tell it what to do. The app really fails to live up to the high-quality of the learning content it could unlock. A major redesign could turn this into the greatest learning tool available. I love my Echo, and I love my Pimsleur, but they are currently not two great tastes that taste great together.

title: Get em tested!
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 21, 2020
content: Please keep in mind your dog can be allergic to so many things..it took time but we eventually discovered why our lab mix was licking and nawing  at his paws all the time. He was allergic to chicken among other things. And if you ever look at the ingredients on pet food, treats, chews, whatever, and even if it says beef, turkey, etc on the description, odds are you will find some sort of chicken by product in it. And that‚Äôs all it took. So after we discovered that, we needed to find something to help him. When we took him to the vet and they did a full allergy test, he was also allergic to weeds, polllen, molds, dust mites, and other stuff. We live in the mountains with 4 seasons. He loves to swim and be outside all the time. It was crazy he was allergic to a lot his environment. Luckily there are meds for all of it and he‚Äôs been doing fine for 10 years now. Just gotta be ready for spring and fall. Point is, just because something might be working well relatively speaking, don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs all they need! Go get em tested! It‚Äôs worth the time, money, and most of all you and your pets can enjoy life to its fullest! Especially theirs, they‚Äôre not here to long so help them make the best of it no matter what. Find products without all the crap in it and your dog will live a longer and greater life..I guarantee it!

The least little thing will cause her to vomit. Since she was young I have made her food from fresh cooked meats and veggies like baked/broiled chicken, sweet potatoes, gr beans, broccoli, boiled eggs, low fat cottage cheese, baked salmon, etc., and switched the ingredients around every so often. This has worked well but I wanted to try Dr. Martys' food because of all the wonderful ingredient it contains. I'm starting the food today along with her regular food, hoping she will eat it since she's been used to eating fresh cooked food! I do whatever it takes for their health and well being, i love my furbabies!  Will keep you posted ....

title: No value for money
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 10, 2021
content: First of all, many cats won't eat fish so if you cat is one of those then skip this product. So if your cat doesn't like fish it's probably not going to like the freeze dried food, either dry or wet.  Second, the package is only 12 oz for $60!  If you have one cat and a decent income that might be doable.  I have 5 cats and even if any one of them would eat the food, which they didn't, I'd have to buy about 2 packages a month. If they cared more about your animal's health and less about their profit margin, the food would be more affordable.  They took to returns, but you'll pay for shipping the product back to the company.  They claim they're "too small" to have those arrangement with a package delivery carrier.

title: Lots of interesting facts about hemophilia - good first release, and hopefully more facts and features to come.
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 21, 2017
content: Aidan, I think you are off to a great start with this Alexa skill! I had a lot of fun playing with it, learning tons of new things about hemophilia!I'm sure you have lots of great ideas for what you'll do next with this skill, but here are a few ideas that you can think about:- Add intents to support questions and answers ‚Äì eg: ‚ÄúAlexa, ask hemophilia facts, how is hemophilia treated?‚Äù- Allow skill to stay open for a conversation,  eg ‚ÄúAlexa, open hemophilia facts‚Äù. The skill will give a greeting, and then stay open to allow the user to interact with it, by asking for facts, or asking questions‚Äù. When user is done, allow skill to be closed by saying ‚Äúclose‚Äù or ‚Äúgoodbye hemophilia facts!‚Äù.- Add a ‚Äòhemophilia quiz‚Äô game ‚Äì Alexa asks questions and the user tries to answer correctly.  -  For extra points, have the skill ‚Äòremember‚Äô the user‚Äôs last score & high score, and use this information in the interaction- Add ‚Äòhemophilia jokes‚Äô to inject some (tasteful) humor into an otherwise serious subject (is it possible to tell hemophilia jokes that wouldn‚Äôt be in bad taste?)- Add ‚Äòhemophilia stories‚Äô ‚Äì play short real life stories (few minutes) to engage users and help them understand how hemophilia impacts the everyday lives of people who have it, and their families, and how they adapt / cope / conquer.- Add response cards to the skill so Alexa can send related web page links or images to the user, shown in the Alexa App. Or better yet, get one of the new Echo Show devices, and have the skill display relevant images or video clips on the screen.Obviously some of these will be easier to implement than others. Have fun with it, and I can't wait to see what you do next!Good luck!

It was clearly a partisan tactic. I chose this app because I enjoy history and learning something new each day. In my listing of flash briefings, it was grouped in the entertainment and educational lineup - not news and politics. Keep your politics out of it. My other Alexa choices are for that reason.

title: pretty good, needs work
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 25, 2019
content: I am a musician and I started using bamboo music when I began teaching music lessons in order to understand my students better. I think the skills taught are useful but the app needs work.for example, most of the songs for ‚Äúname the instrument‚Äù are always played by the same instrument, the forte pieces are always forte, adagio pieces are always adagio...this encourages memorization more than true recognition.also, it is not clear how to earn badges. I have stayed stuck on level one with six badges for weeks and the same questions are getting recycled with me giving the same correct answer everytime. it would be better if once a badge is earned for a category, those questions arent asked anymore.

title: Buggy and limited
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2016
content: I tested it, and got some wrong answers. It said that red red red was 3 K instead of 2.2 K and red red green was 3 Meg. Although most answers were right, it is hard to trust an app that may give wrong answers. What if you build a device using this app and use the wrong resistors?  Also, it is somewhat hard to use. Each time, you have to say "Alexa, open Resistor Color Decoder" and then wait for it to ask for the colors and then say the colors. It would be nice to have a shorter name like "Resistance" and the ability to just say something like "Ask (name) brown black green". Also, it would be really useful to be able to do the opposite, ask for a value like 3.3. Meg and have it give me the colors. When I am building a circuit, I is usually know the value of the resistor I need and want to get the colors to look for, not looking at each resistor and trying to decide if it will work.

skillname: Computers Storified in Viking History by Floki
title: Storification of computer technology
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 9, 2016
content: If this skill is disabled, Alexa will hear Loki instead of Floki.  Once the skill is enabled, the call word Floki will be recognized.  Loki is part of standard Alexa dictionary, while Floki is enabled by this skill.Listen to stories connecting the Vikings with modern computer technology.  Why do people today go berserk at the keybaord or where does the Bluetooth icon come from?Floki had this to day, too:The Internet and the World Wide Web are different.  The Internet is a network, the web is a system of documents.  Oceans and rivers were like the Internet for Vikings allowing for connectivity.  The ships were arriving at monasteries and cities, which were like the world wide web documents located in specific places.In 793 AD the Vikings attacked from the sea shore the monastery in Lindisfarne, England. This radically changed the security assumption that the sea protects the flank of a town. It was not thought possible, wrote one cleric after the first attack, that such an inroad from the sea could be made.  Computer security specialists often encounter completely new vulnerabilities of varying risk.  Zero day vulnerability means that the vendor didn't expect hackers could ever exploit the software hole.

title: Wonderful! -- Dunning-Kruger meets idiot-(vague hints of) savant.
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 15, 2018
content: My first extended interactions with ELIZA were almost 40 years ago, on my Apple ][. I had known about it, and maybe even had a few brief interactions before that, but punch cards and printouts weren't suitable for dialog, and my terminal time in the 1960s and 70s was allocated to higher priorities - though I think maybe I did have one ELIZA session by teletype. I've just been playing with an Android ELIZA and being reminded how awful/wonderful it was. Even with voice input (tap the mike, speak, read the on-screen response, repeat). Then it occurred to me to see if there was an Alexa skill. This is WONDERFUL! With voice-to-voice, the content is still awful, but often awfully funny. The quick responses, the banterlike interactions, the inanity ... It helps that my younger daughter (and mother of my grandsons) is named Eliza. This is the Dunning-Kruger Effect embodied in a digital idiot-savant, with only vague hints of the savant (who was hiding behind the curtains). I was delighted to just read that Joseph Weizenbaum originally created it on an IBM 7094, the computer model I first learned to program (FORTRAN IV and MAP assembler)

title: The same ELIZA program, now with voice!
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 7, 2016
content: ELIZA is a computer program created in the 1960s, and is well known as being one of the first chatterbots created. Nowadays, ELIZA is quite simplistic compared to newer and more advanced AI chatterbots, but it was highly regarded at the time. The ELIZA program originally accepted text input and responded in a similar fashion. The Alexa version turns the text based conversation into a more natural speaking conversation, with voice responses based on what you say. It's kind of a minor change but it definitely makes the conversation experience more immersive. The responses I got back definitely sound just like ELIZA, matching the text based version's very closely.ELIZA pales in comparison to more modern chatterbots, but it is still fairly convincing to this day. The change from text to audio is a small yet big impact on how the conversation is experienced, and it makes things more fluid and natural. For having some fun speaking with an historically important computer program, the ELIZA skill works great in achieving that goal.

title: It's ELIZA, not Alexa. Use your fancy Echo to ask Wikipedia about it before you start griping.
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 29, 2016
content: No, the ELIZA program is not a modern program. No, it is not very good at faking intelligence. No, it will not be your therapist. Was it an important first step in the field of emulating conversations in the field of artificial intelligence? Absolutely! For those with no sense of history: Yes, this application mirrors the ELIZA program. Yes, this application's Voice UI is designed appropriately. Yes, it will be boring and seem like nothing more than a parrot when viewed through the eyes of a person who's grown-up exposed to the advanced AI systems available today.Dev: I commend what you've done and thank you for putting this piece of history in-front of people on a platform that it truly is conducive to.

title: Entertaining skill!
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 5, 2015
content: I honestly feel this skill is solid‚Ä¶ For what it is.For beginners, remember this is only for entertainment. Please read that last line again.That said, it can be a blast and rather intuitive. It really just helps you talk through your own issues,One way that I find it useful as an author is I use it to help a character go through his/her problem. Just take on the persona of the character, and have her/him talk to a therapist. It can actually be pretty fun!Again I do want to stress: this is just for entertainment, and nothing else. As entertainment I feel it's great. One of the best skills out here. Even though it does tend to get caught in a loop occasionally, repeating something nonsensical that you may have said, which is the only reason I don't give it five stars.However, I find it a very useful tool for writing.

title: You do have to understand, and make allowances for, what Eliza is
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 17, 2021
content: Eliza was an early experiment in just how minimal a program could be and still appear to be responding to the user's free-text input. It only knows how to take some basic statement structures and rephrase them as questions -- or, when the statement doesn't match one of those, it will fall back on standard conversational prompts ("Tell me about your childhood", "How does that make you feel", and so on) and hope that the new input will be in a form it can rephrase as a new question. Better versions also stored some statements and would sometimes use those as fallbacks, with "Earlier, you said..." or "Is this related to when you said...". Some versions had a few more statement structures that they would try to apply, or made some effort to notice key words in the conversation -- but the basic Eliza was only a few pages of programming.If you understand its limitations and are willing to work with it -- and forgive its frequent failures -- Eliza is an amusing example of Artificial Stupidity masquerading as AI. You shouldn't expect more from it than entertainment and an illustration of just how bad early attempts at natural language systems were. "The impressive thing is not how well the bear dances, but that it dances at all." [*]Weisenbaum was reportedly somewhere between horrified and furious when he found that some folks in his lab were actually trying to use it for self-analysis. In my experience, it actually has about the same value for that purpose as doing a tarot reading -- the responses are nonsense, but sometimes trying to make sense of the nonsense is a good way of getting yourself to consider interpretations that hadn't previously occurred to you. At best it's another way of talking things through with yourself, which can be bad or good depending on why you're doing so and how you're listening.Don't expect a chatbot. Expect, at best, the verbal equivalent of a fun-house mirror.[* And yes, I know how dancing bears were traditionally trained, and I know it's inhumane; the point here is that Eliza does better than she has any right to ... because her programmer has essentially tricked the human into doing all the hard work.]
